title: russian oligarch vladimir putins hockey partner set britains
story: He is Russia’s wealthiest oligarch and perhaps its most influential a nickel magnate who in his spare time plays ice hockey with Vladimir Putin. But a Court of Appeal ruling on Thursday risks taking a large dent out of Vladimir Potanin’s vast fortune. Senior judges have given Natalia Potanina, his ex-wife, the green light to pursue the 60-year-old through the English courts – despite the fact the Russian courts orced them seven years ago.If her financial claim is successful, the orce payout will be the most lucrative in British legal history and worth up to £10 billion.The  understands that Mrs Potanina is seeking half her ex-husband’s fortune, estimated by Forbes magazine at just under £20 billion, making Mr Portanin the world’s 55th richest man and, according to reports, the wealthiest documented billionaire in Russia.Mrs Potanina, 59, was awarded in the region of £30 million by a Russian orce court in 2014 but the Court of Appeal, sitting in London, ruled that she is entitled to bring a new claim here.“Everything is, however, relative. The wife's settlement represented only a tiny proportion of the vast wealth of this family, all of which had been accumulated during this very long marriage.”She said that since Mrs Potanina was still in her 50s at the time, then “arguably the sum she received would nowhere near meet her long-term needs when considered by reference to the lifestyle to which she had long been accustomed”.Mrs Potanina, who made London her permanent home in 2017, could be in line for a payout of as much as £10 billion if she wins the orce battle.That sum would easily dwarf the previous English record for a orce settlement of £453 million that another Russian billionaire, Farkhad Akhmedov, was ordered to pay his ex-wife. The world’s biggest payout is the $38 billion that Jeff Bezos reportedly paid to his ex-wife MacKenzie.The court heard that Mr Potanin and Mrs Potanina were childhood sweethearts who met as teenagers and married in their homeland in 1983 when both were in their early 20s. The couple, who have three children together, began married life impoverished but, in her ruling, Lady Justice King noted that Mr Potanin “accumulated vast wealth” in the 1990s at the fall of communism.Mr Potanin, according to Forbes, is worth just under £20 billion having made his fortune acquiring a stake in Norilsk Nickel, the world’s largest producer of refined nickel, during Russia’s privatisation in 1995. He currently owns a little over a third of the company, according to Forbes, as well as other assets. Mr Portanin reportedly owns three luxury yachts and spent $10 million on his daughter’s wedding in the south of France. He is described as an “ice hockey buddy” of President Putin.The Potanins’ long marriage faltered with Mr Potanin claiming the couple separated in 2007 although Mrs Potanina insists they did not split up until 2013, by which time “unbeknown to her”, Mr Potanin had a child with another woman – now his second wife. Mrs Potanina said her husband’s announcement that the marriage was over was a “devastating bolt out of the blue” and led to a Russian orce in 2014 and a further “blizzard of litigation”.In the English stage of their long-running court battle, Mr Potanin had won the first round by blocking his ex-wife's attempt to bring a case against him in London in November 2019, when a High Court judge ruled that her claim was an example of orce tourism.But, in Thursday’s ruling, the Court of Appeal cleared the way for Mrs Potanina to bring what could be the highest-value orce case in English legal history.Lady Justice King ruled the decision to prevent Mrs Potanina from making an application for financial relief in England should be overturned, saying: The matter will therefore proceed to trial.The judge added: The fact that the appeal has been allowed and that the wife may therefore proceed to make an application... for financial relief should not be taken by either party as an expression by this court of any view as to the merits or otherwise of that application.Mrs Potanina previously argued she was the victim of a grave injustice and was not given a fair share of the marital wealth because of her ex-husband's wealth, power and influence in Russia.Her lawyers told the Court of Appeal in January that Russian courts deal with orce settlements by equally iding the parties' assets, but do not share any assets owned through trusts or other corporate vehicles.This meant Mrs Potanina's attempts to get half of the assets ultimately owned by her ex-husband have been fruitless, the Court of Appeal said.In the court's ruling, Lady Justice King – sitting with Lords Justice David Richards and Moyland – said the High Court wrongly overturned a previous decision allowing Mrs Potanina to bring a claim for financial relief in the English courts.Lady Justice King concluded: In the event that the parties cannot reach some sort of compromise in this long-running and expensive litigation, the case will be determined with the benefit of oral and, I anticipate, expert evidence by a High Court judge in due course.The legal battle pits the two doyennes of orce lawyers against each other. Baroness Shackleton, who represented Sir Paul McCartney, is acting for Mr Potanin while Frances Hughes, who has spearheaded a number of groundbreaking orce cases, has been hired by Mrs Potanina.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: channel 4 sell under consideration
story: NewsChannel  sell off under consideration within this Parliament, says Culture SecretaryOliver Dowden said there was a case for considering the best future operating model for the publicly owned broadcaster, which is largely commercially self fundedmirrorShareCommentsByLizzy BuchanPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY News " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeMinisters are considering selling off Channel  as part of a review of public service broadcasting. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said a decision on whether to privatise the broadcaster could be taken within this parliament. Channel  was launched in  as a publicly owned, largely commercially self-funded public service broadcaster.Mr Dowden told MPs yesterday that the rapid expansions of streaming services like Netflix and Disney+ meant ministers needed to look again at its future.“I think there is a case for considering the best future operating model for Channel ,” he told the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee.  “That will be one of the things we would consider in legislation in the next session. “We would also look at video on demand and whether there are further reforms that need to be taking place there.” Asked whether they were looking at the privatisation of Channel , he replied: “That is one of the options that is under consideration, yes.” Channel  has been contacted for comment. Mr Dowden also suggested that the Government could step in to help struggling festivalsthey cannot get commercial insurance. He told the committee that his focus was on reaching June  - the final stage of the roadmap- when remaining Covid restrictions could be lted.  If festivals cannot go ahead after that point then the Government could step in he said. Mr Dowden told MPs: “Once we get to that point,it is the case that events still can’t go ahead because of a lack of insurance and the failure of the commercial insurance market, we stand ready to look atwe can use Government intervention in exactly the same way we did with the film industry.” He added: “It has to be the case first that we know can something go ahead. If the final barrier to stop that happening is the lack of commercial insurance, that is the point in which we would contemplate acting.” But Tory MP Heather Wheeler said it was “too late” for many festivals, adding: “I just feel we’ve lost probably another summer because they can’t get insurance.” Meanwhile, Mr Dowden also confirmed that talks on hosting the Champions League final in England had stalled because UEFA wanted to bring , people for the match.  He said the Government was unable to give an assurance to UEFA we would be willing to y our quarantine rules in the way they wanted to happen. They wanted to bring a large number of people to the match, thataposs fine, itaposs the issue about quarantine, he said. We would expect people entering the UK except in very, very exceptional circumstances to observe the quarantine rules. AskedUEFA would cut back on guests, he said: Itaposs for UEFA to answer those questions. We had a very constructive discussion with UEFA and it was a genuine dference that couldnapost be overcome. I respect the decision that UEFA made and I think they respect the fact that the government wasnapost able to move on it. Asked how many people, he said: It was ,.FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnUEFAChannel UEFA Champions League FinalPublic servicesPolitics

title: david cameron boasts paid far
story: NewsDavid Cameron boasts he was paid far more by Greensill than he was as PMThe former Prime Minister refused to put a figure on his potential payday from the doomed financier - but said the reported figure of £m was "completely absurd"mirrorShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY NewsThe PM gave evidence to the Treasury committee " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeDavid Cameron was paid far more by Greensill Capital than he was as Prime Minsiter, he boasted to MPs today. And he said he didnapost know why he signed off his texts Love DC - but admitted he did so with anyone he knew even at all well. The former Prime Minister was grilled by a Commons committee about his lobbying of ministers on behalf of the now-collapsed financial firm. He admitted: I was paid a generous amount - far more than I was paid as PM. And I had shares - not share options, but shares in the business which vested over the period of time of my contract. So itaposs important for the committee to know that I absolutely had a big economic investment in Greensill. I wanted it to succeed. I wanted it to grow. I havenapost put a number on those things, because ...the amount isnapost particularly germaine to these questions and is a private matter. But the ex-PM insisted his motivation for calls and texts to ministers asking for help on behalf of the firm was not just financial, but because he thought the firm had solutions that were in the interests of the public good.  Asked why he signed off some texts to officials with love DC - the ex-PM said: Anyone I know even at all well I tend to sign off with text messages aposlove DCapos, I don’t know why, I just do. My children say you don’t need to sign off text messages at all. Mr Cameron said he said abided by the rules that were in place, but added: Rules alone are never enough. We learnt that in this place over so many issues, personal conduct and codes of behaviour, and how such conduct and behaviour both appears and can be perceived, these things matter too. I completely accept that former prime ministers are in a dferent position to others because of the office that we held and the influence that continues to bring. We need to think dferently and act dferently. He said lobbying the Government was never intended to be part of his role at Greensill Capital until the coronavirus crisis.In his opening statement to the Commons Treasury Committee, he said: In terms of my role, I was not employed at Greensill as a lobbyist and lobbying the UK Government was never intended to be part of my role. However, in the economic turmoil caused by Covid, the Government, quite rightly, introduced several schemes to help ensure that credit would continue to be expanded to business. The Greensill proposal was to make this even more effective and I believed that it should be considered by Government.FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnDavid CameronPoliticsCoronavirus

again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAfter months of stalling, Boris Johnson has finally agreed to establish an inquiry into the coronavirus pandemic. The case for an independent examination of how ministers, scientists and the NHS responded to the biggest public health ­emergency for a century was incontrovertible. We need to know why Britain ended up having one of the highest death tolls in the world, why the NHS was not prepared for such a crisis, why it took so long to provide PPE. Those who have lost loved ones to the virus are rightly furious the Prime Minister has delayed this inquiry until the spring of . If there is, as Mr Johnson has suggested, a strong likelihood of a winter surge then we should have at least an interim investigation now so lessons can be learned which may help prevent further deaths. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  By deferring the inquiry for a year the Prime Minister has clearly calculated the findings will not be published until after the next election. Not for the first time he’s putting his personal interests before those of the country. Fears of war There are concerns the violence in Jerusalem and Gaza could escalate into war. The Israeli military has responded to rocket attacks by Palestinian militants by unleashing a wave of air strikes.  Brokering a ceasefire is imperative and urgentwe are to prevent the loss of more civilian lives and stop the situation descending into a conflict which risks engulfing other parts of the Middle East. The international community must exert whatever influence it has on the Israeli and Palestinian leaders. Then work must once again begin trying to find a lasting settlement based on the two-state solution. Pay a flat fee  Despite earning £, a year it appears Boris Johnson has trouble paying some of his bills on time. Thankfully, the Prime Minister and First Lord of Treasury is not in charge of the nation’s finances. Oh hang on...FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnBoris JohnsonPublic inquiryPoliticsCoronavirus

title: corrupt cop who helped gangsters
story: NewsCorrupt cop who helped gangsters steal from rivals in Line of Duty-style plot jailedFormer PC Kash Mahmood, , was described as "audacious, corrupt and criminal" after confiscating hundreds of thousands of pounds from traffickers during fake stopsmirrorShareCommentsByTom Pettor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMahmoodwas pictured with some of his co-defendants in Dubai" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA bent cop who helped gangsters steal from their rivals in a Line of Duty-style corruption plot has been jailed for eight years. Kash Mahmood, , was described as audacious, corrupt and criminal after confiscating hundreds of thousands of pounds from traffickers during fake stops. Sentencing him at Southwark Crown Court on Thursday Judge David Tomlinson said Mahmood abused his position of power, trust and responsibility. Mahmood remained impassive as he was led to the cells in blue shirt and black facemask. Judge Tomlinson said he would have known he was putting iniduals in danger by leaving those he stole from vulnerable to reprisals from their underworld bosses.Got a story  Email webnews@mirror. Addressing the former PC and his co-defendants, the judge said: “aposIt must have been plain to all of you that these couriers were being put in harmaposs way.” Mahmood was allegedly tipped off about who to target by the Dubai based mastermind of the organised crime group who was using an encrypted EncroChat phone. Mujtaba Neazmand, an Afghani national, left the UK in  after being made the subject of a proceeds of crime order and is believed to be there now.  Detectives would not be drawn on whether he is wanted in the UK. Hundreds of top and middle level organised crime figures have been arrested after the EncroChat phone network was hacked by European law enforcement last year. The court heard how Mahmood had become the first in his family to go to university, after avoiding the pull of criminal gangs while growing up in east London.  He had been stabbed as a teenager for refusing to get involved in crime, his barrister Bill Emlyn Jones said. But after ten years as a successful officer with five commendations his “background caught up with him”, the court heard. Mr Emlyn Jones said: “He thought he had escaped it, but it pulled him back in.”  Mahmood jetted off to Dubai where he was pictured with his co-defendants and splashed out on a £, Rolex watch. The court heard he was a longtime associate of gangster twins Shabaz Khan, , and Shazad Khan, , and their brother Moshin Khan, . He misused police computers to check what intelligence was held about the brothers and Neazmand. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Mahmood, of Harlow, Essex, admitted conspiracy to acquire criminal property and misconduct in a public office at an earlier hearing. He was kicked out of the Met last year after a disciplinary  found he had driven a police car while his associate posed as a police officer to seize cash which was due to be laundered or was payment for drugs. Mohsin Khan was sentenced to  years for conspiracy to supply class A drugs, conspiracy to transfer criminal property and conspiracy to acquire criminal property.  Shabaz Khan was jailed for  years for conspiracy to supply class A drugs, conspiracy to transfer criminal property, conspiracy to acquire criminal property and possession of a controlled drug of class B with intent to supply. Shazad Khan was sentenced to  years and five years and four months in jail respectively for conspiracy to supply class A drugs, conspiracy to transfer criminal property and conspiracy to acquire criminal property. Ioan Gherghel, who dressed as an officer while accompanying his friend Mahmood on the raids, was jailed six years for conspiracy to acquire criminal property. Moshin Khanaposs ex-partner Maria Shah, , admitted supplying class A drugs and conspiracy to acquire criminal property and was sentenced to five years and four months. Scotland Yardaposs Deputy Assistant Commissioner Bas Javid, Directorate of Professionalism, said: “Mahmood may have been a police constable in name, but he was nothing more than a criminal who abused his position to look after the interests of organised crime.” Steve Noonan, of the Independent Office of Police Conduct, said: “This officer’s behaviour was audacious, corrupt and criminal. His actions were a complete betrayal of public trust and confidence and have no place in policing.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnMohsin KhanScotland YardCourt caseCrown courtPolice carCrimeTeenagersTwinsKne crime

Boris Johnson has warned the B. strain, which is currently ravaging parts of India, is of increasing concern in Britain.Official figures set to be released on Thursday are expected to confirm a worrying three fold increase in infections of the highly transmissible mutation. Experts advising the Government believe the final stage of Boris Johnsonaposs road map out of lockdown - set for June  - could now be pushed back. And it is believed that there will be an emergency meeting of the Governmentaposs SAGE advisers tomorrow to discuss the iant. Surge testing has been introduced in areas such as Bolton, Greater Manchester to help stem the spread of cases.  The Mail Online reports analysis by one of the UKaposs iant trackers has warned the strain is focused on hotspots in Bolton and nearby Blackburn with Darwen.There outbreaks are said to have grown by  and  per cent in a week, respectively, and more than half of cases found to be the Indian strain. It is also reported to be behind half of Covid infections in London, Bedford and South Northamptonshire, but these outbreaks are still small.Citing data from the Wellcome Sanger Institute The Sun reports that Bolton is the UKaposs epicentre with  positive Covid tests caused by the Indian strain up to April , representing  per cent of Covid cases in seven days. Nearby Blackburn with Darwen reportedly saw  cases identied, representing . per cent of the areaaposs total. In South Northamptonshire nearly  per cent of cases were the India iant while Bedford saw . per cent, representing  cases.Members of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies will assess the threat at a meeting today, reports i news. A member of the committee told the publication that “a delay is possible” for lockdown easing in England.  Asked about a possible delay to the June  easing, Tory minister James Cleverly told Sky News: “Scientists on SAGE will make assessments, they will report that to government, and we will make decisions based on the data, the evidence they provide. “The Prime Minister and the Health Secretary have always been clear that the easing of restrictions which allows us to get back to normality will be done at a pace and in a way that is safe. “We will always be driven by the data.” With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. If this figure is confirmed by Public Health England in its weekly update, it would be treble the  figure from seven days earlier. Ministers have not ruled out re-introducing local lockdowns in areas where the iant of concern is increasing.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnCoronavirus

title: girl 5 left orange faced
story: NewsGirl, , left orange faced after getting hands on mums fake tan that lasts for daysEllie had asked to used her mum Louise Birchleys moisturiser but appears to have picked up the wrong container, and end up looking a bit like Bart SimpsonmirrorShareCommentsByBeth KilgallonNilufer Atik:,  MAY NewsEllie before she got hold of the dark tan " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA five-year-old girl was left orange faced after getting her hands on her mumaposs fake tan. Louise Birchley had been taking a nice relaxing bath at home when her little girl, Ellie, came in with a dark glow on her hands and face. The -year-old mum quickly realised that the youngster must have been playing with her fake tan and hurried out of the bath to wash it off before it had a chance to develop further. Louise said: I was just in the bath when Ellie shouted to me and asked to use my moisturiser. I said yes because she asks to borrow it regularly, so I didnapost think anything of it. The next thing I know, she walks into the bathroom and her face and hands were dark brown.  I was in shock when I first looked at her. I was like aposoh my godapos and jumped out of the bath to try and wash it off as quickly as possible before it started to develop. It was a new bottle of tan that I had bought that day. I hadnapost used it before, so I had no idea what the outcome was going to be, however, the bottle said aposdark tan. lasts for daysapos so I had a feeling I wasnapost going to be able to get it off her easily. After trying to wipe off as much of the tan as possible, Louise knew it would be a case of waking up in the morning to see how tanned Ellie would be.  Unfortunately, the next day the youngster’s skin was an orangey colour, and Louise said she resembled Bart Simpson. When I woke up the next day and saw her orange face, I couldnapost believe it. It almost looked like she had jaundice,” she said. She also had a really dark patch on her chin which she obviously hadnapost rubbed in hard enough. And as she had just applied in with her hands, they were just as orange as her face. I was actually thinking about tanning the rest of her body to give her an even colour, rather than her face just being tanned, but I decided against it and hope it would quickly fade. Ellie claims she didnapost know she was using fake tan, but she definitely knew what she was doing. She is such a girly girl and loves everything about hair, makeup and tanning.  She has seen me putting fake tan on myself, so she probably wanted to experiment with it. Louise says that Ellie seemed pleased with herself and the results of her tanning session until she went to school and people kept telling her she looked tanned. When she woke up I think she actually was quite chuffed with the job sheaposd done. Although her older sister, Mia, nine, was so embarrassed that she refused to hold her hand and walk into school with her. I then had to explain to Ellieaposs teachers what had happened and why she was going into school with an orange face,” Louise explained. She started to get more embarrassed about her tanning incident when she arrived at school and people were asking her about it. It took about three days before the colour started to fade. Iaposll have to keep an eye on my bottles of fake tan from now on.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnEducationSchoolsFake tanThe Simpsons

Kamran Khan was racing his RS at more than mph over the limit when he collided with another car, which smashed into a church. More than a dozen people were injured in the terrying incident in Leeds in , including five children. Khan, , was arrested and pleaded guilty to two counts of causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He was jailed for three years during a sentencing hearing at Leeds crown court earlier this month. Got a story  Email webnews@mirror.  The court was told that Khan was driving his powerful vehicle - capable of speeds of up to mph - in wet conditions on a busy road. He then lost control and collided at speed with a Peugeot , which smashed into a Universal Church of the Kingdom of God. This vehicle hit several people, including a baby in a pram - which was trapped between the car and a wall. Most of the injuries were minor but one woman suffered a serious injury to the foot, the court was told. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  As well as a custodial sentence, Khan, from Leeds, was also banned from driving for six and a half years. PC Steve Harrison, of West Yorkshire Policeaposs Roads Policing Unit, spoke after the hearing. He said: While sentencing him, Judge Mairs repeatedly talked about Khan’s flagrant disregard for traffic laws. On that rainy day back in September , Khan chose to drive over twice the speed limit and caused a crash which injured multiple adults and children. It is sheer luck that only two people were seriously injured and that the consequences were not even more serious. The court were told Khan had a previous conviction for a drug driving offence and had cannabis in his system at the time of this collision. Khan has been jailed for his actions and I hope this sends a clear message of the dangers and consequences of driving at excessive speeds whilst under the influence of drugs.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPeugeotWest Yorkshire PoliceCCTVCCTV footageCourt caseCrown courtPrison sentenceDriving banDangerous driving

story: NewsopinionI caught hubby searching for gay men online - what sort of man uses a women to hide A reader asks agony aunt Coleen Nolan what to do about her marriage after being shocked by what she saw on her husbands phone - something which made her feel usedmirrorShareCommentsByColeen Nolan:,  MAY NewsopinionConcerned readers husband was searching for gay men online" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeDear Coleen, My marriage is at crisis point. The other day, I saw my husband’s phone light up and, for some reason, I took a look at it.From the notication, it was clear he was looking for gay men in our local area. While our marriage isn’t great, what sort of man uses a woman to hide behind his true self  This makes a complete sham of our entire le together and I feel totally used. I could really do with some advice on what to do.Coleen saysWell, you can’t unsee it or forget about it, so the only way forward is to tell your husband what you saw and ask him for an explanation. He needs to answer all your questions honestly and talk about where you go from here.  He might have been confused about his sexuality for a long time or it might be something that’s more recent. The only way to know is to ask him. Of course you feel betrayed and that your relationship has been built on a lie – it’s completely natural in the circumstances – which is why it’s important to talk to him to get the full picture. Whether or not he’s had sex with another guy, the intention is there. From secret feuds and sexy scandals to the biggest showbiz headlines - weaposre serving up a daily dose of gossip.Get the inside scoop on all your favourite celebs with our daily newsletter delivered straight to your inbox for free.You can sign up here.  And, obviously, it will be hard for you to move on as a couplehe’s constantly fighting the urge to live as a gay man. Honesty is what’s required and then I think you have to focus on yourself and what you want for your future. And don’t be embarrassed to ask for support from people you trust. The marriage has obviously been struggling for some time and this seems to provide an explanation.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnColeen NolanRelationships

title: i hand reared fox cub
story: NewsI hand-reared a fox cub who thinks Im mum - it lives in bathroom and cuddles my poodleEXCLUSIVE: Belinda Rose took in the baby fox after it was brought into her vets and mistaken for an abandoned puppy and now keeps him in her downstairs bathroom which she has covered in tree branches and leavesmirrorShareCommentsByEmma Dunn:,  MAY NewsBelinda Rose with the adorable cub" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA woman has hand-reared a fox cub who thinks she’s its mum - and it lives in her downstairs bathroom and cuddles up to her poodle. Belinda Rose, , took in the baby fox after it was brought into her vets and mistaken for an abandoned puppy. Belinda took him home to nurse him back to health and now keeps him in her downstairs bathroom which she has covered in tree branches and leaves. The fox - who she has not named so she doesn’t get attached - was so small it weighed g but after five weeks in Belinda’s home, in Newmarket, Suffolk, he has grown to .kg and has become more fox-like. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  Belinda has now given the fox cub to a rescue centre - which has other baby foxes for them to continue to recuperate before they are let back into the wild. Belinda, a vet, said: “He was so tiny when I got him. His eyes were closed and he was just a ball of fur so he did look like a puppy. “Every day he has grown and he loves to still snuggle up for a cuddle.  “I’ve had to resist naming him so I don’t get too attached and want to keep him.” Belinda was on a night sht when the cub was brought into her vets. She realised it wasn’t a puppy as initially thought, but in fact a tiny abandoned baby fox and gave it powdered milk.  Realising it needed proper care, Belinda brought the fox to her home and made it comfortable in her downstairs bathroom. “I covered it in leaves and trees,” she said. The baby fox soon started to grow and now eats a diet of meat and dog biscuits.  “He is adorable,” Belinda said. “But he has always had an attitude. “Once I lost him for seven hours and he had crawled behind a bathroom .  “When I found him he came straight for a cuddle.” He is now lapping up milk and eating for himself and gets on well with Belinda’s rescue poodle, Arthur. “They snuggle up next to each other all the time,” she said. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  “Now the fox is bigger, they will play together too.” The fox had been with Belinda for five weeks and has just left her to join a group of other foxes his age to then be released back into the wild in three to four months. “I’m sad to see him go,” Belinda said. “He’s got a special place in my heart.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnFoxesAnimals

title: inside covid hotspot bolton cases
story: NewsInside Covid hotspot Bolton as cases surge and locals beg: Give us all the jabEXCLUSIVE: The Mirror paid a visit to Bolton, as a new surge in case makes the Greater Manchester town one of the country’s virus hotspots and residents want the whole town vaccinated - and fastmirrorShareCommentsByAmanda KilleleaBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorMartin Bagot:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsIn Bolton as the town experiences a spike in infections " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeIn Bolton town centre the message from the Government is clear -you have symptoms get a test. But for locals enjoying the sunshine in front of the huge Covid information sign in the town hall square, testing simply isn’t going far enough to tackle the new surge in cases making Bolton one of the country’s virus hotspots. Residents here want the whole town vaccinated - and fast - to prevent another local lockdown like they had last year when most of the rest of the country saw restrictions begin to lt. The infection rate in the town was the second highest in the UK at . cases per , people last week and cases of the Indian iant have risen dramatically in the area. This and the fact infections are also increasing in the under s in the town has led to both Greater Manchester’s mayor Andy Burnham and Bolton North East MP Mark Logan to call for vaccinations for all over s. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  Shopkeeper Mohsin Nazir, , saw his business shut during lockdown and urged everyone to get vaccinated. He said: “I’ve just heard about this new iant that has come from India or somewhere. I think they need to be vaccinating everyone now. I’ve had my vaccine. We just want to get back to some sort of normal le, no more lockdowns, everyone working again.” Carol and Peter Marsden have both been vaccinated but are still very worried about the surge in cases in Bolton.  Retired cook Carol, , says: “They definitely need to start vaccinating the younger people. It is the younger people we see not wearing masks and ignoring social distancing. If people refuse the vaccine they should have to stay at home.” The sudden rise in infections in Bolton is believed to be driven by the B... strain of the virus, often called the Indian iant. It is thought to have been brought into the town by people travelling back and forth from India and Pakistan. There is also a spike in London while an outbreak is Glasgow is also thought to be linked to the iant. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here.Just days before the next lting of lockdown in England is due to take place on Monday, PM Boris Johnson admitted on Thursday he was “anxious” about the new strain.Speaking at a primary school in Ferryhill, Co Durham, the Prime Minister said: “It is a iant of concern, we are anxious about it. At the moment there is a very wide range of scientic opinion about what could happen. “We want to make sure we take all the prudential, cautious steps now that we could take, so there are meetings going on today to consider exactly what we need to do. “There is a range of things we could do, we are ruling nothing out.”  Askedlocal lockdowns were possible, Mr Johnson insisted: “We want to make sure we grip it.” He added: “Obviously there’s surge testing, there’s surge tracing. If we have to do other things, then of course the public would want us to rule nothing out.” But he was confident a spike would not derail Monday’s latest planned unlocking, with Step Three of the Government’s “roadmap” due to be triggered – allowing households to mix indoors, and pubs, restaurants and cafes to serve customers inside.Government scientists were expected to meet on Thursday to discuss the rising coronavirus threat from the Indian iant in Britain. Some members of Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesare believed to be pushing for a delay to the final stage of Boris Johnson’s roadmap out of lockdown set for June . Leading expert Prof James Naismith, of Oxford University, said the iant may spread “way beyond” the local areas where it has been detected. “I think we should view it as a country-wide problem,” he said. “It will get everywhere. We keep learning this lesson, but we know that this will be the case.”  Prof Naismith said he did not believe local restrictions would work to contain the iant, adding: “When we tried locally having dferent restrictions in dferent regions that didn’t really make any dference. “So I don’t think thinking about a localised strategy for containment will really work.” The prospect of a potential future local lockdown is the last thing the people of Bolton want resident Carol adds. “I will be annoyedthey lock us older ones down again when we have stuck by the rules.” Her husband Peter agrees. The retired sheet metal worker, , said: “I heard that people travelled from India. But surely they should have been isolating I don’t understand why international travel hasn’t been banned - this new iant has to have come from somewhere.  “Also I think public transport is a problem in Bolton. When you get on the bus there are a lot of people not wearing masks. The drivers don’t seem to be enforcing it. The older people do, but the younger ones aren’t.” Fishmonger Lee Morris, , who works on Bolton Market, added: “I’m very worried about it - rates in Bolton are now among the highest in the country.I’ve had the vaccine and I feel more confident now that I’ve had it because I work with the public every day. “I think rates in Bolton are high because young people aren’t sticking to the rules - socialising, parties. I do think they should offer younger people the vaccine but that only worksthey take it.I think people are dodging it because they are scared of it. “If they lock us down again I will be devastated. It will have a massive impact on the market.” Students Reia Raichura and Jamiee Patel disagreed that young people were to blame for the spread of the virus - but also had quite dfering views on what to do to stop it.  Jaimee, , had Covid herself last November and lost her grandma to the virus. She has had both vaccines and believes that all young people should be offered it. She said: “I was quite ill and my grandma passed away. I had to isolate for four weeks to see her in her last days. I think everyone should be offered the vaccine now as well as antibody tests.” Her friend Reia Raichura though is still worried about the vaccine - even though cases are rising at their sixth form college. Reia, , said: “We have been sticking to the rules. But I feel it is getting out of hand now. I think they need to think about closing the schools and colleges as well. There have been people testing positive and having to isolate at our sixth form. “I’m still not sure about the vaccine though.” Yesterday the Office for National Statistics announced that seven in ten people in England now test positive for Covid- antibodies, suggesting either vaccination or prior infection. The number was closer to six in ten for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. The European Medicines Agency said on Wednesday that it was “pretty confident” that vaccines currently in use will be effective against the Indian iant. Prof Steven Riley, of Imperial College London, who runs the UK’s biggest Covid- surveillance study, said there was no indication that the iant was increasing hospitalisations. He said: “I think there’s two key things that have got to be kind of evaluated -infections go up, how quickly will they go up  But then after that, are they linked to the hospitalisations  “The top-line Government policy is driven by protecting the NHS, so eveninfection starts to go up, we then need to assess whether that’s bringing a lot of new cases into hospitals, and there’s certainly no sign of that at the moment.” The B... iant is now claiming around , lives a day in India where vaccination rates are much lower.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPoliticsCoronavirusMutant Coronavirus

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeKate Middleton appeared to channel Diana by wearing a polka dot dress with striking similarities to one she wore decades earlier, during a series of royal visits today. The Duchess of Cambridge was seen dressed smartly in a blue and white polka dot blouse, matching trousers and blazer as she visited young people in the West Midlands. Her mother-in-law was known for her obsession with the patterns and was seen in dferent coloured outfits over her years with the Royal Family. Prince William, , and Kate, , have been visiting dferent youth centres as part of a series of events to mark the UKaposs national Mental Health Awareness week, which is now in its st year.  The royal couple were pictured having a whale of a time as they participated in dferent youth activities, while they were seen giggling away as they faced each other in a ping pong game. Their first stop on Thursday was at The Way Wolverhampton Youth Zone, an organisation that provides sports, arts and recreation activities for youngsters every night of the week.  After visiting the Youth Zone, the royal couple moved on to visit Base, a charity that supports young people who have dficulties in accessing mainstream services. The last stop on Thursday was at the HugglePets charity, where children with SEN disabilities or other challenges are supported through the use of Animal Assisted Therapy. This yearaposs Mental Health Awareness Week focuses on nature as an important tool to not just improve oneaposs wellbeing but also prevent and help recovery from mental health issues.  It comes after the Mirror reported earlier this week how Kate spent time talking to a mum and her daughter about how her generation has been affected by the Covid- lockdown.The Duchess of Cambridge spoke to Niaz Maleknia over the phone about her portrait aposCancelledapos, which was among the  selected as part of the aposHold Stillapos National Portrait Gallery exhibition spearheaded by the Cambridges.She then spoke to her daughter Ronny, who is the subject in Niazaposs portraits and who told the duchess that while mental health among youngsters hasnapost been great, it was positive to see that more people were openly talking about it. The Duchess agreed as she said: Absolutely, everyone has sort of experienced something together in a way so there is no shame in talking about it and thataposs what weaposve been really keen to do, itaposs break that stigma and start those conversations around mental health.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeRoyal FamilyMental healthTherapy

title: men detained home office released
story: NewsMen detained by Home Office released after hundreds of protesters block van on EidHuge crowds have been stopping the immigration enforcement van from leaving since this morning, with many in the street expressing disgust that the action is taking place on EidmirrorShareCommentsByLucinda CameronEdward DracottMilo Boyd:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe protesters have blockaded the van in the street " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Home Office has been forced to release detained men after huge crowds came out to protest their removal on the religious holiday of Eid. The move comes hours after the first Glaswegians blocked the van this morning in protests which saw a man placing himself under an immigration enforcement vehicle.Riot police arrived at the scene this afternoon where crowds chanting leave our neighbours, let them go blocked the van from leaving. Shortly after pm Police Scotland announced that Chief Superintendent Mark Sutherland had ordered the men, detained by UK Immigration Enforcement, to be released back into the community. The crowd roared and cheered as the men were let out of the van, with the person at the front bowing forward in a prayerful thanks.A Police Scotland spokesman said: Around .am this morning, police were called to an address in Kenmure Street, Pollokshields, following a protest by a large group of people.  Mohammad As, director of the Afghan Human Rights Foundation, was one of what he said were hundreds of neighbours protesting against the action on Thursday, when Muslims across the world are celebrating Eid. The -year-old said: Weaposre here against the hostile environment created by the Tories and the British state. The same people who run from the British and American bombs put at the back of the van right now. And they are about to be deported. And itaposs on Eid you know... the guys are not even allowed to pray. How do you do that in a democratic society  Itaposs a sad day.  Mr As, who left Afghanistan as a refugee himself in , said the atmosphere amongst the protesters is peaceful.Sabir Zazai, chief executive of the Scottish Refugee Council, wrote on Twitter : Not close to the details on this but this is shocking, disgraceful and racistpeople are raided by enforcement officers amidst the pandemic on the day of Eid.Wafa Shaheen, head of services at the charity, said she was shaken and angry at the Home Officeaposs decision to force people from their homes on the first day of Eid, and she condemned the heavy-handed approach. Tom, a neighbour who joined the protest, compared the immigration operation on Eid to a police raid on Christmas Day.  The solidarity shown today shows the community will not stand for their neighbours being dragged from their homes, the -year-old, who did not want to give his surname, told PA. Iaposd ask Christians to reflect on what it would feel like to have your house raided on Christmas Day. Lotte, an artist and member of the Scottish tenants union Living Rent, lives on a street nearby. She said she joined the protest when she saw a small group outside the property on Kenmure Street at am on Thursday. Iaposd like to express my utter disgust at the brutal removal of my neighbours from their home, the -year-old said. It is an awful thing to do on any day, but today being Eid makes it  times worse. I hope they will let our neighbours go.  Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon accused the Home Office of creating a dangerous and unacceptable situation with the action. Ms Sturgeon, who was sworn in on Thursday as MSP for Glasgow Southside, tweeted: As constituency MSP, I am deeply concerned by this action by the Home Office, especially today in the heart of a community celebrating Eid.  My office is making urgent enquiries and stands ready to offer any necessary assistance to those detained. Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said he was disgusted by the Home Office raids. He tweeted: It is particularly unacceptable that this is happening during a pandemic, in an area that has a spike in cases and on the day of Eid. A Home Office spokesperson said: “The UK Government is tackling illegal immigration and the harm it causes, often to the most vulnerable people by removing those with no right to be in the UK. “The operation in Glasgow was conducted in relation to suspected immigration offences and the two Indian nationals complied with officers at all times“The UK Government continues to tackle illegal migration in all its forms and our New Plan for Immigration will speed up the removal of those who have entered the UK illegally.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnAnas SarwarNicola SturgeonMohammad AsLabour PartyHome Office

Patrick Mackay, , dubbed the “Monster of Belgravia”, strangled two old ladies and butchered a Catholic priest with an axe.But Mackay confessed to eight more killings - then denied it. All of the attacks remain unsolved. Police were asked to probe the cases in , delaying his parole hearing. The board has now decided not to make findings of fact in relation to those cases due to the “passage of time” and “absence of complete evidence”. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  It said in a decision summary released on Thursday: “The  found that it should consider some of the allegations but decided that these did not affect its assessment of Mr Mackay’s risk.” Mackay was  when he was convicted of strangling and stabbing Isabella Grfiths, , in Belgravia, central London in  and Adele Price, , a year later. He was further convicted of murdering -year-old Catholic priest Anthony Crean in the Kent village of Shorne in .  Mackay, who has changed his name to David Groves, was jailed for le for manslaughter, by reasons of diminished responsibility. Another  offences were taken into consideration by the trial judge, including robberies and thefts. He had also been charged with two further murders, which denied committing, which were ordered by the trial judge to “lie on file”.  MacKay has been in open conditions since . The  said it considered a dossier of more that  pages and heard evidence from his probation officer, the official supervising his case in prison, a psychologist and an independent psychologist. The parole board said: “After considering the circumstances of his offending, the progress made while in custody and the evidence presented at the hearings, the  was not satisfied that Mr Mackay was suitable for release.  “However, on assessing the benefits and risks of Mr Mackay remaining in open conditions, the  recommended that he should stay in the open estate.” Among the unsolved murders Mackay admitted and then denied was that of cafe owner Ivy Davies, , who was axed to death at her home in Southend, Essex, in February . title: partner outstanding dad tried revive
story: NewsPartner of outstanding dad tried to revive him in front of heartbroken kidsAmelia Louise woke up to find her partner blue in the face and unresponsive at their home in Wrexham, prompting a desperate and unsuccessful attempt to save his lemirrorShareCommentsByAaran Lennox:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsAmelia Louise has paid tribute to her long term partner Damien Jones " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum desperately tried to revive her partner in front of their two young children. Damien Jones went to bed laughing and joking with his partner Amelia Louise on Monday night.When she woke up the next day the -year-old, who went by the name Dash, was blue in the face, Daily Post reported. Amelia Louise frantically tried to revive her partner of eight years while children David-Lloyd, , and Esme-Rose, , watched on. Sadly her efforts proved in vain. Dash was pronounced dead on Tuesday by paramedics when they arrived at the family home in Wrexham.  A bereft Amelia Louise said: I am heartbroken and I feel empty, my le will never be the same but I must remain strong for our babies. We went to bed as normal on Monday, laughing and joking no issues and when I woke up he was just lay there, so still, blue in the face and as I called out his name and started shaking him I knew there was an issue. After having doing CPR for more than -minutes, whilst our babies lay there watching I couldnapost accept when the ambulance told me he had passed. Amelia went on to express the depth of her loss. He was my king and I was his queen, together forever we told one another, she said. After trying for years to build a family, having lost several babies this was all Damien wanted, a le where he could be happy in himself and the people surrounding him.A GoFundMe page has now been set up by family friend Samantha Davies to support the family to help with the funeral costs.Amelia explained how much that gesture meant to the family. Damien was loved by so many people, and his heart had room for everyone, she said. My friend Samantha started the fundraiser and I canapost thank everyone enough for their donations and messages theyaposve sent me over the past few days. David-Lloyd and Esme-Rose are all I have left of him and the fundraiser will ensure Damien gets the send of that he fully deserves. The fundraising page describes Damien as a top lad, the light of the party and lit up everyone’s hearts with his laughter and character. The fundraiser has been set up with an initial target of £, which will help fund a white horse and carriage. Any additional money raised over the amount needed for the full costs of the funeral will be donated to a charity fund of the family’s choice. The family have stated they are awaiting the results of a post-mortem to find out the cause of Damienaposs death. They said he had popped into hospital on the Saturday with breathing issues but was sent home due to being told it was believed to be muscular pain.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnFuneralsTributes

The Duke spoke about how his le changed since quitting as a senior member of the royal family and moving to America with Meghan and now two-year-old Archie. Harry, , said in London he became used to making constant attempts to stay under the radar while out and about - often wearing baseball caps and walking with his head lowered. In a bid to keep themselves out of the spotlight, Harry revealed he and Meghan even met in disguise at a supermarket for one of their dates.He said they pretended not to know each other to try and stay aposincognitoapos, adding: I had a baseball cap on, looking down at the floor, trying to stay incognito. Speaking on the Armchair Expert podcast, he said: Living here now I can lt my head. I feel dferent, my shoulders have dropped. You can walk around feeling a bit more free. I take Archie out on the back of my bike.. The Prince recently said Calornia has now become his spiritual home where the anger of the past has gone, a journalist who once interviewed the duke has claimed. Journalist, author and mental health advocate Bryony Gordon said that the Duke of Sussex now had a sense of purpose after his move to the US.  Bryony previously got Harry to open up about his mental health battle in the wake of Princess Dianaaposs death in her podcast in .In an article for the Dailyshe said that Harry, now living in a  million mansion in Montecito with his pregnant we Meghan and son Archie, had found a sense of purpose after leaving the Firm last year. title: prince harry shares 3 times
story: NewsPrince Harry details the three times he felt truly helpless and needed therapyPrince Harry said he felt "completely helpless" in three moments of his le including when he was being chased by the paparazzi while in the car with his mum Diana and when he was in AfghanistanmirrorShareCommentsByTim HanlonClaire Gilbody-DickersonNews reporter:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPrince Harry has revealed the three moments he felt completely helpless in his le " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePrince Harry has spoken of the three times in his le where he felt truly helpless as he opened up about how he has sought therapy for anger management.The Duke of Sussex, , said he used to repress the anger connected to the constraints of being part of The Firm and the inevitable media glare that came with it.It was only thanks to a conversation with his we Meghan, , that he realised he needed help, he told Dax Shepard on the Armchair Expert podcast. Recollecting that moment, he said: It was a conversation that I had with my now we, and she saw, she saw it straight away. She could tell that I was hurting and that some of the stuff that was out of control was making me really angry and it would make my blood boil. .  Harry, who now lives in Santa Barbara with Meghan, told the Armchair Expert podcast: Helplessness, that is my biggest Achilles heel. There were three major times that I felt completely helpless [as a royal], one when I was a kid in the back of a car with my mum being chased by paparazzi, two was in Afghanistan in an apache helicopter and then the third one was with my we [having the conversation about therapy].  Harry and Meghan explosively announced last year that they were quitting their lives as senior royals to move to Calornia with their son Archie, now two. He told the podcast: In my early s it was a case of I don’t want this job, I don’t want to be here, I don’t want to be doing this. Look what it did to my mum, how will I be able to settle down, have a we and a family when I know that it is going to happen again because I know. I’ve seen behind the curtain, I’ve seen the business model how this operation runs and how it works, I don’t want to be a part of this.  Then when I started doing therapy suddenly the bubble was burst […] you are in this position of privilege, stop complaining or behaving as though you want something dferent, make this dferent. Harry also revealed he met we Meghan in a supermarket and compared his le as a Royal Family member to The Truman Show, the Daily Star reports. The interview with Dax comes two months after the Sussexesapos bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey, in which the couple spoke about the issues they had within the Royal Family. In the interview, first aired on CBS and then ITV, Harry and Meghan explosively claimed concerns were raised by a senior member of the royal family over how dark their son Archieaposs skin tone would be.Oprah then followed up on the conversation saying it was neither the Queen or Prince Philip who had made the remark.Meghan also told the US chat star how she felt like The Firm had failed to give her the support she needed when she felt suicidal pregnant with her son. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePrincess Charlotte is set for a series of dramatic title changes when her grandad Charles and later her dad William become king, say royal experts. There will be some major shake-ups in the Royal Family when the Queenaposs reign comes to an end, and several senior members will be in line for new titles and new roles when Charles ascends to the throne. Charlotte, who turned six earlier this month and is fourth in line to the throne, could eventually inherit her great aunt Princess Anneaposs title. The Princess Royal title is traditionally given to the eldest daughter of the monarch, but it doesnapost happen automatically and it is up to William to decide whether Charlotte inherits the title. Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here Regardless of who is king in the future, Charlotte will always retain the style of Royal Highness.Until then, she will have a number of title changes during the reigns of Charles and William. When Charles becomes king, she will become Princess Charlotte of Cambridge and Cornwall and likely Princess Charlotte of Wales when her father becomes the Princes of Wales. But she would lose the Princess of Wales title when William becomes king and her older brother George inherits the Prince of Wales title.  Instead, she wouldto being Princess Charlotte.Her mum Kate Middleton would become the Queen Consort, though she is likely to be referred to as Queen Catherine. The celebrity gossip YouTube channel OSSA explained Charlotteaposs future will only change dramatically when her father succeeds his grandfather as king.  It added: “When that happens le as Charlotte knows it will look very dferent, in fact, there is a good chance she’ll lose her titles when her dad is on the throne. “By the time William is King of England, his eldest son George will be Prince of Wales. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. The young royal would become Charlotte of nothing, the report added. OSSA said: “Her right to be Princess of Wales flies out the window when her brother gets the official title of Prince of Wales because a royal lady can only be a princessshe’s married to a prince or the daughter of a prince. “As George’s sister, Charlotte doesn’t fit either category.” Charlotte could become Princess Royal when William is king. The Princess Royal title comes with a lot of responsibilities and strict rules to abide by, especially when it comes to dating. Under ancient British law, anyone who sleeps with the Princess Royal before getting married to her is guilty of treason, which was once punishable by execution, royal expert Duncan Larcombe has explained in the past. He reckons it is most likely that dad William will bestow Charlotte with the Princess Royal title once she marries. Mr Larcombe previously told Town and Country: The title of Princess Royal is traditionally bestowed on the eldest daughter of the monarch. Princess Anne had to wait until  before her mother the queen bestowed the title of Princess Royal on her, even though the title had been vacant since .FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPrincess CharlottePrince Charles, Prince of WalesPrince WilliamRoyal FamilyThe Queen

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA thirsty punter ended up hanging upside down on a pubaposs railings after trying to sneak into its beer garden to grab an empty bench by clambering over a fence. Pub-goers were left in hysterics after witnessing the embarrassing mishap as they enjoyed their drinks at The Hope and Anchor in Royton, Greater Manchester. Stunned onlooker Nicole Meadows was enjoying a drink at her local on Friday evening when she spotted the daring duo attempting to land a vacant bench. In the hilarious clip, one of the women attempts to step over the fence but appears to get her foot stuck and is trying to disentangle herself from that while her pal decided to e over herself. The second woman flings herself over the railing but the waist of her jeans becomes caught on the metalwork, flipping her the wrong way up and leaving her suspended upside down for more than  seconds.  As -year-old Nicole and other witnesses cackle in the background, the unknown woman is finally helped back over the fence by a stranger who comes to help. Once freed from her predicament, the woman announces aposIaposve hurt my vaginaapos to entertained customers before askingshe can have a seatshe walks around to the proper entrance. Nicole, from Middleton, Greater Manchester, said: It was hilarious. Iaposve never seen anything like that before. It was highly amusing. Everybody was laughing. Theyaposd closed the doors because the pub was full, but there were still a couple of empty benches outside.  The girls were trying to climb over the fence to sit at one of the benches and get served. The doors were closed and there was a sign outside saying they were at full capacity on a blackboard. But itaposs an open beer garden and you can see [the seating]. The first girl managed to get over, but the second one didnapost.  The care worker had been with her mum Vicky Meadows when the chaotic scene caught the attention of the entire beer garden, who all watched on in amusement. In her clip, Nicole can be heard laughing hysterically as the two unknown women became stuck in the awkward positions. Nicole said: Everyoneaposs going wild because everythingaposs reopened. Itaposs got a really big beer garden. Somebody sat at the back of the pub [got up to] try and help her over. [After the incident] she just accepted the fact they werenapost allowed in and tried going somewhere .  I think she wrapped her legs around it to try and save herself from smashing her face open. Margaret Newton, landlady of The Hope and Anchor, said she asked the two women to come back another time and was glad they didnapost come to any harm. Margaret said: The door was shut, she tried to get in and she wasnapost served. Thataposs the only thing I can say. I told her to come back later on when it might have died down, but she didnapost do. I havenapost seen her since. I did ask her to come back. I said aposwe are full love. Iaposm not serving youapos. Iaposm just glad she didnapost hurt herself. Itaposs a light-hearted story. I have no problems. They do tend to climb over the fence. If they climb over the fence, the rule is they donapost get served. Iaposll just be glad when we can get back to normal. Weaposll be able to welcome people back in and save all this hassle.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPubs

title: queens tribute philip touching choice
story: NewsQueens tribute to Philip with touching choice of dress for State Opening of ParliamentRoyal fans noticed the Queens outfit choice for the State Opening of Parliament held a special signicance and tribute to the Duke of EdinburghmirrorShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  MAY NewsThe Queen delivering the Queens Speech " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Queen paid a touching tribute to Prince Philip with her dress choice for the State Opening of Parliament. On Tuesday, Her Majesty outlined promises from the Government as she carried out her first major public ceremonial duty since the death of her husband. Fans noticed her outfit choice held a special signicance and tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.A tweet from a royal fan pointed out: The Queen is wearing the same dress she wore on the photograph released for Prince Philip ’s th birthday.For the Queenaposs Speech, the Queen wore a long blue coat with a matching dress adorned with yellow flowers, and a coordinating blue hat, by Angela Kelly.  It was the same dress the Queen wore in a portrait of her and the Duke of Edinburgh on his th and final birthday. For the first time in  years, the consortaposs throne that is usually placed next to the monarch for the event was absent, following the sad death of Prince Philip last month. Instead Prince Charles followed his late fatheraposs example to take his motheraposs hand and provide support during the formal event.  But it meant that much like Philipaposs funeral, the Queen was pictured alone in a striking reminder of her sad loss. The ceremony did not have all of the pomp and circumstance of a normal State Opening, with no horse-drawn carriages or page boys. Much of its pageantry was missing because of Covid restrictions still in place despite the easing of lockdown measures in England.  The Queen set out the Governmentaposs post-pandemic agenda outlining a raft of new laws the PM hopes will help him fulfil his promise to tackle inequality and level up the country. It included promises to receive more tailored and preventative care through the NHS, to provide measures to tackle obesity and mental health and to bring proposals on social reform forward. She also said proposals will be brought forward to create and support jobs, to support a letime skills guarantee and to help businesses drive economic growth.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnState Opening of ParliamentThe QueenPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghRoyal FamilyPolitics

title: twenty month old baby girl
story: NewsTwenty-month-old baby girl hit by car towing caravan died in tragic campsite accidentThe toddler, who has not been named, was pronounced dead at the scene after she was hit by the vehicle on Wednesday. It is believed she died at Little Trethvas Holidays campsite near Ruan MajormirrorShareCommentsByNick Irving:,  MAY NewsThe -month-old was killed on a Cornish campsite" %, rgba, rgba, url"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.Sign Up!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA -month-old girl on a family holiday has died in a tragic campsite incident. The toddler was killed in a collision with a car towing a caravan on private land. She was pronounced dead at the scene shortly after the emergency services arrived yesterday afternoon. Devon and Cornwall Police said: Police and paramedics were called to a campsite in the Helston area following a report of a collision between a vehicle and a child at around .pm on Wednesday May . Tragically, the child, a -month-old girl from the Nottingham area, was pronounced deceased at the scene. Her family is being supported by specially trained officers.  The collision involved a car towing a caravan and happened on private land. The air ambulance also attended the incident. The coroner has been informed and an investigation by officers from the specialist Roads Policing Team continues. The dead child has not been named, but her next of kin have been informed. It is thought the fatal incident happened at the Little Trethvas Holidaysapos campsite near Ruan Major. Staff there have declined to comment on the incident. The campsite holds pitches for tents, campervans and caravans, but also has two one-bedroom cottages and a holiday home sleeping up to six. Helston is situated at the northern end of the Lizard Peninsula approximately  miles east of Penzance and  miles south-west of Falmouth. The A was partially blocked while emergency services attended, with an air ambulance also called to the scene.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnDevon and Cornwall PoliceFamily holidays

title: woman transforms ordinary looking home
story: NewsWoman transforms ordinary looking home into incredible s replica with time-warp interiorCrossing the threshold to Hannah Halls home in Nottingham is like stepping back in time, with a s interior complete with patterned wallpaper, vintage furniture and a rotary phonemirrorShareCommentsByLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  MAY NewsThe house looks ordinary from the outside " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA woman has transformed her home into an incredible time capsule that feels like youaposre stepping back into the s. Hannah Hall bought a s-era home in Nottingham with her mum and began fitting out the interior with a decor from another era, such as patterned wallpaper, old appliances and vintage furniture. The kitchen includes black and white tiled flooring, a whistle kettle, exposed wooden beams and an open pantry, and where thereaposs a working rotary phone and a stunning oak wardrobe.aposVintage-obsessedapos Hannah originally bought a working s gas cooker on eBay and has slowly given the home a makeover to match the theme, saying her interest in the wartime period was sparked when her grandparents introduced her to the fashion, film and TV of the time. Her grandparents gave her some of the furniture which now features in the home, and Hannah says - despite owning a TV - she plans to continue to strip back the home instead of turning to modern technology. Hannah said: Iaposve always been interested in vintage things and I get told that Iaposm an old head on young shoulders. When me and my mum moved into the house, it was totally dferent to what it is now and we wanted to unearth its potential. Itaposs my mumaposs first buy because sheaposs always rented homes, so I wanted to make it extra special. The theme really started to take off when we did the kitchen in a s style and we loved it so much that we decided we really wanted to go with that theme throughout the house.  The kitchenaposs finishing touch was the beautul s gas cooker - it works an absolute dream and has inspired us to live a little simpler. The house is kind of like an ode to my grandpa, who was born in . He was a signicant part of my le and really got me interested in the s era as a kid - I was enamoured by his droplets of wisdom. My nanaposs taste in vintage and eccentric fashion has also inspired me to dress quirky. I feel like my home is an adoption centre for vintage things. I absolutely love it but I know itaposs not to everyoneaposs taste because itaposs a massive niche.  After the kitchen was redone, we went a bit mad and just started collecting dferent items such as a -year-old tin opener, vintage wallpaper and old paintings. The gas cooker in the kitchen definitely comes in handythe electricity goes out on our street because weaposre still able to cook dinner. Itaposs not what you expect when you come in and every single room has vintage touches. Our family thinks the house is really quirky and is like a little time capsule. Everyone loves coming over and kicking it a little old school for a bit.  Hannah says when they bought the home from an old family friend everywhere was rather beige and needed an overhaul having lost its charm. The renovation work uncovered the original floorboards and staircase, which bought it back to le a bit.While continuing to add to her s home, Hannah posts videos of the project on her @Realvintagedollshouse TikTok account, saying: Vintage items have a bit more soul than modern things and I get a kick out of finding something that might have so much story behind it.Iaposm a big believer that we should honour the past and I donapost think younger people these days necessarily appreciate how dferent things used to be. Reminding people that it wasnapost always like this hopefully helps them appreciate how far weaposve come. Weaposre still working on the house every day and weaposre hoping to get a s-style front door and also transform the back garden, using my grandpaaposs old Raleigh bike as a flower feature.What do you think of the home  Let us know in the comments. FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnHousing

news weird-news dads-disappointment-over-having-girl-"ByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  May An expectant dadaposs reaction to the gender of his new baby has ided opinions online.Matt shared footage of his gender reveal party on TikTok, where heaposs known as @matthb. In the clip that has been viewed more than , times, Matt and presumably his partner can be seen surrounded by their loved ones - all of which are clearly very excited to see the sex of the baby. When the time comes to pop the balloon, Matt takes hold of it firmly as his partner pops it with a pin.Pink balloons, confetti and silly string appear - indicating the pair are expecting a little girl.  But whilst the rest of the family are seen celebrating the exciting news, Matt simply throws the popped balloon on the floor and mutters something inaudible.Since being posted, the video has racked up more than , likes and hundreds of comments from ided viewers.One person wrote: Don’t worry.
