I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: plans-second-substation-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-lodged-council
story: The latest planning application, from Seagreen Wind Energy, shows a substation built on top of a former gasholder site stretching across paths which the firm admits may have to be erted.Seagreen sparked local concern when its initial consultation appeared to put the entire Greenhills in its proposed site.However, the plans now lodged with the council show the substation across the road from the former Cockenzie Power Stationrsquos main footprint on an old gasworks area now being used for a temporary car wash business.Acknowledging concerns raised by community councils over the loss of green space, Seagreenrsquos application says: ldquoAs far as possible, the proposed substationwill be sited to avoid any areas of habitat value. Where not possible, we confirm that any potential loss of woodland or scrub would be compensated for by post-construction landscape planting.And they added that any loss of existing footpaths was still to be discussedto agree how to mitigate it, adding: ldquoThis will likely involve a ersion to the existing footpath. If this is required, we will seek to minimise theof this ersion as far as possible.Seagreen currently has apoundbn offshore wind farm development under construction after it was granted exclusiverights for the Firth of Forth Zone of the UKrsquos Round  offshore wind farm development programme.Phase One within the zone includes the development of two offshore wind farms ndash Seagreen Alpha and Seagreen Bravo ndash located more than km from the Angus coastline.Work is already under way to bring the energy online at a number of sites, with Cockenzie the latest to be put forward.The former Cockenzie Power Station site was bought by East Lothian Council from ScottishPower after the stationrsquos iconic chimneys were demolished.It has been marketed by the local authority for projects, with a visionary masterplan setting out a wide range of employment, energy and recreational uses for the large -hectare site and surrounding area.To date, a substation which will bring energy onshore for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd is the only proposal given planning permissionfor the site.Seagreenrsquos proposals cover a nearby area of land outwith the power station footprint itself, including a beach car park next to it, where underground cables would be brought on land, under the main road and into the National Grid inshore.The proposal includes an onshore substation, underground electricity cables and ldquotemporary and permanent infrastructure to export electricity.

title: brunton-musselburgh-reopen-month
story: Audiences will be welcomed back to Venue  from May  as the team works to programme a range of theatre and concert screenings, with singing stars Michael Ball and Alfie Boe on screen on July  and co-founder of the band Fleetwood Mac, Mick Fleetwood and Friends, confirmed for September .Movie highlights get under way with Nomadland on May , Ammonite on June  and Minari on June .In line with Scottish Government regulations, The Brunton has a range of modications in place including signage, floor markings, sanitiser stations, enhanced cleaning schedules, face coverings, reduced capacity in the auditorium and advance booking only. Staff will be on hand to offer a warm welcome and answer any questions visitors have.The trust will continue to follow Scottish Government guidance and hopes to be able to resume live performances in the not-too-distant future as restrictions ease.Michael Stitt, chairman of The Brunton Theatre Trust, said: ldquoWe are delighted to finally be opening our doors again to welcome back our audiences from the local community and beyond.ldquoWorking with East Lothian Council, we have taken considerable steps to ensure a Covid-safe environment within our much-loved venue.ldquoCareful consideration will be given to the type of programming that we hope will be possible in the coming months, with the safety of our audiences and staff at the forefront of our artistic decision-making whilst always adhering to Scottish Government guidelines.Donations of any size are welcomed to help The Brunton continue to bring a programme of arts and entertainment to East Lothian and beyond.Financial contributions can be made via The Bruntonrsquos website thebruntonFull details of the cinema programme can be found on The Bruntonrsquos website.Further details about enhanced protocols and online ticket booking are also available at the venuersquos website.

title: burgh-primary-school-pupils-images-make-people-smile-bid-raise-money-playground-improvements
story: Pupils from  classes took part in a competition on the theme lsquoSomething That Makes You Smilersquo during the Easter holidays to produce photos for a school calendar which will be sold in aid of the playground project.Avril Campbell, reporter for the Musselburgh Courier, had the tough task of choosing winners on an anonymous basis and the results were announced at school assembly last Friday.The overall winner was lsquoSunset In The Harbourrsquo, by Romilly Upcraft, P, which will appear on the front page of the Burgh Primary  calendar.The other winners were: lsquoBarbies and My Friend Jackrsquo by Clara Bose, nursery lsquoThere Are Eggs Under There!rsquo by Anna Thomson, P lsquoDaffodil Picturersquo by Vinnie Dunn, P lsquoEtta In The Parkrsquo by Lily Doherty, P lsquoI Love Ice Creamrsquo by Caroline McDonough, P  lsquoPeek A Baarsquo by Ava Virlogeux, P lsquoBassie The Guillemotrsquo by Ophelia Carter, P  lsquoHeidirsquo by Lily Fisher, P lsquoSpring Bunniesrsquo by Erica Olds, P  lsquoBooks Hearts and Flowersrsquo by Anya Peet, P lsquoWinter Wonderlandrsquo by Angus Ross, P and lsquoThe Bridges rsquo by Lauren Hollingsworth, P.Avril said: ldquoIt was a very dficult decision as the standard was very high and the pupils were so imaginative with their subjects.S Luca of Musselburgh kindly donated chocolate treats for all the children who entered the competition.Jon Doyle, headteacher, said: ldquoOur all-weather pitch no longer has adequate goals, our adventure log-trail is intermittently closed due to disrepair and, vitally, surfaces and facilities need to be made safe and accessible for our wheelchair users.ldquoWe value the support of our parent council in working with us to make our playground area everything it can be for our children and community.The parent council has also organised other fundraising initiatives, including Easyfundraising, a school lottery and a local scavenger hunt.

Labour had dominated the Scottish Parliament elections in East Lothian since the constituency was created in .Iain Gray has been the countyrsquos MSP for more than a decade but announced he was stepping down from the role earlier this year.Labour had hoped that former MP for East Lothian Martin Whitfield could follow in his footsteps and ensure the party continued its grip on the seat.However, Mr McLennan won by more than , votes from the Labour candidate, with the results announced at Meadowmill, near Tranent, earlier this afternoon .The newly elected MSP said: ldquoI want to give special thanks to Iain.ldquoHe has been MSP for a long time, mostly here in East Lothian, and Iainrsquos presence will be missed in East Lothian.ldquoI want to thank my fellow candidates ndash Craig , Euanand Martin .ldquoIt has been a very dferent campaign and probably the first time we have seen each other since the virtual hustings.Mr Gray and Mr Whitfield were among the first to congratulate Mr McLennan, who is also a councillor for the Dunbar and East Linton ward on East Lothian Council, on the victory.The result was the first seat to change hands today .Mr McLennan secured , votes , with Mr Whitfield in second spot on , .Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor Craig Hoyfinished in third with , votes , with the Liberal Democratsrsquo Euan Davidson in fourth with , votes .The result gives Mr McLennan a majority of , ndash the biggest majority in the county since .He described the victory as ldquoprobably the most humbling thing in my le and said: ldquoIrsquove lived in East Lothian all my le.ldquoIt is the most fantastic county, it is the best county, and I am incredibly humbled to represent it.ldquoMy pledge is to work with all groups in East Lothian and to work with all political parties in East Lothian because that is incredibly important.Mr Whitfield served as the countyrsquos MP from  to  but could not secure the Holyrood seat.He spoke to the Courier shortly after the results were announced and said: "Im very disappointed."It was very close and at the end of the day it has been a very, very strange election."All of the little evidence and things that we look for were unavailable this time and we were unable to knock on lots and lots of doors and speak to people, which has always been a very positive campaign strategy for Labour."The teacher at Dirleton Primary School echoed the comments of Mr McLennan in paying tribute to Mr Gray.He described him as a "phenomenal MSP" and was saddened he was "unable to carry the baton forward".He added: "East Lothian is a stunningly beautul place."The people here are massively important and I know that Paul will serve them very well and remember it is the constituents here that elected him."Mr Hoy also paid tribute to Mr Gray, who became the countys MSP in .He said: ldquoI hope that those who follow will rise to the level of service set by Iain.The Conservative share of the vote was down just over three per cent on the results from , when Rachael Hamilton also finished third.Mr Hoy added: ldquoWe fought a very positive campaign, a good campaign, very well run, but we could not get round the simple observation that it was a Labour-held seat and we were in third position.Mr Davidson felt the Liberal Democrats had been ldquosqueezed between the top parties.However, he was hopeful the party would enjoy more success through the regional vote, with the results yet to be announced.A total of , votes were cast, which is a . per cent turnout.A total of  votes were rejected, with five voting for more than one candidate and the remainder unmarked or void for uncertainty.

title: mp-calls-a1-renamed-queens-highway-platinum-jubilee
story: Conservative MP Sir Edward Leigh wants the A renamed the Queenrsquos Highway.However, the idea has not met with universal favour throughout East Lothian, where the route stretches from Dunglass in the east to outside Musselburgh and the Edinburgh boundary.Sir Edward told the House of Commons the ldquobeautul Great North Road should be renamed after the Queen to celebrate her  years on the throne next year.Speaking during transport questions, he said: ldquoThe A, the Great North Road, is a beautul road linking Scotland and England ndash and I think, to honour the upcoming jubilee, we should rename it the Queenrsquos Highway why not ldquoBut it is not an entirely safe road. I have spent hundreds of hours on it there are many fatalities on it.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, felt there were more pressing matters than changing the -mile routersquos name.He said: ldquoWhat it needs is upgraded, not a new name.ldquoItrsquoll always be the A for most folk but having it fully dualled would be better.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the Dunbar and East Linton ward, was not in favour of the idea.He said: ldquoI think it is known as the A and donrsquot think it is appropriate to change it to a dferent name.ldquoIt should be known as the A trunk road and calling a road a particular name is not the right thing to do.ldquoThere are many other things that we could name that would be more appropriate for celebrating the Queenrsquos platinum jubilee.Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, also felt there might be a more fitting gesture to mark the occasion than renaming the road.He said: ldquoI think the A suffices for me.ldquoIt has always been the A and always will be the A.ldquoIt is right that they mark the occasion in some manner but I am not sure this would be the way to do it.Preston Seton Gosford ward member councillor Lachlan Bruce felt the idea had merit.He said: ldquoThis idea is worthy of further consideration and it would be an appropriate way to mark Her Majestyrsquos platinum jubilee.ldquoHowever, what was of more importance in his contribution was the need to focus on signicantly upgrading the A.ldquoSir Edward was completely right about that and what we need to see is the A dualled all the way to the Border.An ldquoextra A turn-off was also required to serve the new town of Blindwells, he added.ldquoThat would take away the increased pressure on this vital route that everyone knows will build up there when people start to move into the new town, said Mr Bruce.While Tranent, Wallyford and Macmerry ward councillor Colin McGinn said: ldquoPeople are free to express their beliefs about recognising historic and important figures.ldquoAt this time, however, I feel the focus should be on getting the country on a road to recovery and allow the agencies involved to focus on that work. If there is an opinion that this is a good idea then it could be brought forward at a better time.Musselburgh councillor Stuart Currie agreed there would be other ideas worth considering.He said: ldquoThere are always lots of ideas that come from the House of Commons some make sense and some donrsquot.ldquoYou have to be careful of the costs of having to rename a trunk road going through Scotland to England it would be hugely costly.ldquoObviously, in terms of the trunk road network, as soon as you cross the Border it changes responsibility. I suspect he may have thought it only went to the Border and did not go any further.

title: petition-drawn-urging-dunbar-residents-back-plans-turn-assembly-rooms-flats
story: Alexander Williamsonrsquos attempts to see the vacant areas of the Dunbar Assembly Rooms, which dates back nearly  years, turned into four flats were rejected by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee in March.An appeal to Scottish Ministers is being drawn up, while a petition has been launched urging members of the public to back the proposal, which developers claim is ldquothe only course of action left.The petition, which developers hope will show public support for the plans, has already been signed by nearly  people.It notes that the building was bought at auction in , with permission in place for nine flats. But the planning consent lapsed in , which ldquostarted a long journey over many years and countless sleepless nights worrying for the safety of the residents living below.The petition notes: ldquoUnless we successfully lobby Scottish Ministers with our appeal, my parentsrsquo -year battle to regenerate this building could be lost.ldquoDunbarrsquos town centre regeneration will continue to be held back in favour of large out-of-town developments, risking the lives and livelihoods of local people, while we watch historic buildings deteriorate beyond repair.ldquoYou donrsquot need to look far in Dunbar to see the effects neglect has had on our history.ldquoThankfully, over the past  years, we have managed to maintain the structure of the Assembly Rooms, keeping a roof above the three basement flats below.ldquoThis has not come without expense and eventually the -year-old roof will need removednot replaced.ldquoThis building is older than some of Dunbarrsquos most iconic landmarks ndash nearly  years older than Abbey Church on High Street, for example.ldquoTo put this into perspective, the Assembly Rooms date back to , the same year as King George IV visited Scotland , three years after Queen Victoria was born, some  years before the Victoria Harbour in Dunbar, which was started in .ldquoPlease give us your support in order that we can challenge the decision of our local councillors, bring le back to this building and remove an eyesore from Church Street.The planning committee saw councillors split over whether the scheme, which was supported by the townrsquos community council, should go ahead.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire, who is the planning committee convenor, highlighted parking dficulties as being behind the reason for him opting to vote to refuse the application, despite planning officials recommending it be approved.The petition is at change.org p scottish-ministers-support-dunbar-s-assembly-rooms-planning-consent-appeal

title: plea-save-ground-floor-closed-haddington-pub-keep-business-use
story: Plans were revealed last month to transform the three-storey Gardeners Arms in the centre of Haddington.The historic venue, on the townrsquos Kilpair Street, dates back hundreds of years, with The Fraternity of Gardeners of East Lothian once based in the town.They purchased a property which contained an inn on the corner of Market Street.However, last orders may have been called at the pub, which has not been open for about three years.Flats would be created on each floor of the building under DSI Properties Ltdrsquos plans.Haddingtonrsquos community council did not object to the proposals but felt that the plans could be altered to keep the ground floor available for business use.The proposals suggest the insignia painted on the front of the building would be retained, something which was welcomed by the group.Paul Darling, one of the community councilrsquos planning liaison officers, said: ldquoIrsquom not averse to two flats but would quite like to see the bottom house kept for retail, personally.That view was backed by colleagues Pat Lemmon and Graham Samuel during the virtual meeting.The discussions came after it was highlighted that a number of businesses had moved into neighbouring High Street in recent months, despite the challenges brought by the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown restrictions.Chris McEwan, chairman of the community council, said: ldquoI quite agree with what is being said.ldquoWe have got businesses coming into the town and there have been three opening in recent months, even during the year we have had.ldquoKeeping another retail opportunity there, especially in that part of town, is a good idea.Community councils are given the opportunity to provide their views on any planning application.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department aims to make a decision on the application by the end of the month.The Haddington group agreed to write to East Lothian Council about the proposals, with community councillor John Hamilton suggesting it was ldquoa preference rather than an insistence that the business unit on the ground floor remain in place.A supporting statement included within the planning application highlights the dficulties facing pubs and the lack of apparent interest in someone taking over the Gardeners.It reads: ldquoThe property was sold recently to our client.ldquoIt had ceased to operate as a public house almost three years ago and had been marketed for sale without interest.ldquoThe climate in that market has not been good for some time and will become even more dficult following the current Covid outbreakand the economic fallout from this.ldquoIt is clear that an alternative use for the property needs to be foundit is not to fall into disrepair.ldquoWith this in mind, our clients opted for residential use.ldquoMore and more properties in town and city centres are being given up to residential use in an attempt to bring le back to them and help sustain existing business outlets which have managed to keep trading.

title: artists-selected-bring-special-new-hare-trail-life-families-can-watch-action
story: Leuchie House respite centre, based just outside the town, is gearing up and working hard to launch The Big Hare Trail on July , which is being held in celebration of its -year anniversary as an independent charity.The  giant hares will be placed around North Berwick for  weeks in a free family-friendly trail.More than  entries were submitted to the public art event.And now all of the artists who will prime, paint, adorn and embellish the  hare sculptures have been selected.Each of the fibreglass sculptures has been sponsored by a business and will be inidually decorated in a unique style by the selected artists.Each artist has received a pound commission and the opportunity to work alongside a commercial sponsor.Hares were chosen as one of the most popular and high-profile animals native to East Lothian.Already, artist Emily Hogarth has been announced as an ambassador for the trail.She is being joined by Julia Zeller-Jacques, who runs North Berwick High Street shop Rock  Bird Rachel Marshall of Bonzo Art, whose work can be found in WhyNot  in the town Lorraine Miller, who owns Between the Woods and Sea, a North-Berwick based handmade ceramic and wire sculptures business award-winning North Berwick-based artist Georgina Bown Catherine Rayner, an award-winning author and illustrator who moved from Yorkshire to Edinburgh Chris Rutterford, one of Scotlandrsquos top mural artists, based in Edinburgh Chrisrsquos partner Lubi Lykan Rosie Watson, a Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design graduate illustration graduate Abbie Herriot and local artist Ali Blevins.Lana Bambridge, head of fundraising at Leuchie House, said that the charityrsquos team and sponsors had their work cut out picking the final designs.She said: ldquoWe were absolutely delighted with the response to our callout to artists.ldquoThe calibre of artists was very high, with design entries from all over the UK, but it made the selection process much harder.ldquoMany artists chose an East Lothian-based theme, while others gave due consideration to the work and cause of the charity.ldquoWhat made the designs more impressive were the compelling stories behind the artistsrsquo inspiration. In the end, we have managed to find a balance of styles, themes and unique characteristics. We are keen to showcase the artistic culture that embodies East Lothian and are delighted to have so many local artists represented.All of the hares are currently in production at a lodge-turned-artistsrsquo hub at spa and health club Whitekirk Hill, where they will complete their work.Families are being encouraged to pop along for a sneak peak of the artists at work, with just a matter of weeks to bring their designs to le before they are transported to their designated locations.In a fun addition, there are even lsquopeep holesrsquo for visitors to utilise!Mark Bevan, Leuchie House CEO, said the campaign had created a ldquoreal buzz.He added: ldquoWe wanted to celebrate Leuchiersquos th anniversary in a way that could involve and benefit the community as a whole, by providing a free family-friendly event to inspire young minds and showcase East Lothianrsquos vibrant culture.Each sculpture will eventually be auctioned to raise funds for Leuchie House.

title: vet-column-ball-swallowing-loki-proves-dog-mischief
story: Do remember that, for many pups, le has been unusual in that they were unable to socialise with other dogs and humans, so it may well be a stressful time for them.We all assume our pets are happy because we care for them and keep them healthy, but often little changes in the home environment which we take for granted can be a major change for your pet, resulting in some degree of stress.If you do not spot this quickly, behavioural changes can occur which can take a long time to correct. Not all animals are the same some cats and dogs enjoy noise and excitement, but to others this would be very stressful.Others like peace and quiet ndash but to some, being left quiet and alone is stressful.I think most of us are aware that sudden, unusual noises can frighten pets for example, thunderstorms and fireworks. These are sounds which are strange to your pet and can result in a great deal of stress.In a recent survey carried out by the PDSA,  per cent of owners said their pet was scared of fireworks. The main signs the owners reported were cowering and hiding, trembling and shaking, disinterest in food and barking.Pets left alone either at home or in a cattery or kennel, which are unusual occurrences, can result in severe stress, as the pet feels abandoned by their family.Bringing in a new pet or moving home can also feel terrying for a pet which is used to constancy. Sometimes the dynamics of the pets within a home can change and one or more pet can feel threatened.At Dunedin Vets, at the beginning of lockdown, we saw many problems, especially with cats who were not used to their owners being at home all the time.Cats are notoriously sensitive to change. They may hide their stress but it can manest in other ways.This can include bladder problems and over-grooming and itching.Please contact your vet for adviceyou feel your pet requires some help to overcome their stress-related problems.It is wonderful to be out and about in the spring sunshine, albeit it is a bit chilly at the moment.Remember, there are a few hazards to avoid when walking your dog.Do not throw sticks for them to catch or retrieve. These can cause terrible injuriesthe dog runs onto them and injuries occur in their mouth or, as I have seen, penetrate their skin and damage structures in their necks.Last month, we mentioned the collie dog who was chasing his ball and accidentally swallowed it.Recently, our senior veterinary nurse Nicole saw a young couple rush to the front door of our Tranent surgery, carrying their dog. The owners were obviously very distressed, so Nicole spoke with them and discovered that they were sure Loki, their three-year-old cockapoo, had tried to swallow the bouncy ball toy he had been playing with.Mrs Pamela Masson explained it was a hard rubber ball with rubber spikes on it.Nicole could hear Loki making strange noises when breathing she checked he was able to breathe and called the vet to examine Loki. Gently opening his mouth, they could just glimpse something blue at the back of his mouth.Nicole had previously been involved in dealing with a dog which had choked on a ball. She knew this dog was somehow managing to breathe, unlike the previous one she had dealt with, which was unable to breathe and had been rapidly turning blue.She reassured the owners and admitted Loki for treatment to extract the ball. As choking animals are very distressed, they are likely to panic and bite, although Loki was remaining remarkably calm. The team prepared short-acting intravenous anaesthetic and several pairs of dferent-sized forceps to help extract the ball. Once a catheter was placed in Lokirsquos leg vein, everything had to be performed rapidly as soon as the anaesthetic injection was administered, to prevent the ball falling further into Lokirsquos larynx or dropping into the oesophagus. With Nicole supporting his head and a light being shone into the mouth, the blue spiky ball was seen. Grasping it with forceps, and with some tension and rotation, the vet extracted the offending ball from Lokirsquos throat.The ball had a central hole, or tunnel, running through it. This was the reason Loki was able to breathe, albeit in a laboured, noisy fashion.The ball had lodged with its central tunnel in line with Lokirsquos mouth and larynx. The rubber spikes caused a bit of damage to the soft areas around his larynx, but these would soon heal. Loki recovered quickly from his short-acting anaesthetic and was soon heading home with his parents.It is great to play ball with your dog but make sure youdo play with a ball large enough that your dog cannot swallow or choke.If you are playing with a solid rubber ball, please ensure it does have a central hole right through it.This was undoubtedly the reason why Loki was able to breathe.It also makes it much easier for the vet to remove, as there is something to grab onto. A smooth rubber ball completely stuck in the throat is surprisingly dficult to grasp and remove.I think Loki will be playing with footballs from now on.

title: musician-records-sounds-north-berwick-new-album-series-depicting-seven-continents
story: Ted White, who was brought up on Cromwell Road, where parents Sally and Andrew still live, was approached by music distribution service Platoon to co-ordinate field recordings he had gathered around the world over several years and release them via Apple last month.Each of the seven albums is dedicated to a dferent continent, and the sounds of North Berwickrsquos beaches and harbour feature on the Europe: Earth Sounds album.Ted, , said: ldquoI travel a lot, recording sounds around the world, and Platoon and I collectively came up with the concept of collating my recordings of the past seven years into continents of the world.ldquoI did a bit more travelling to record the bits I didnrsquot have.A former student at Loretto now splitting his time between Liverpool and London, Ted came back to North Berwick to capture the seaside townrsquos night-time atmosphere.He said: ldquoI grew up there so I knew where I could get good sounds without the noise pollution that you get in London.ldquoI recorded lots of midnight sounds on the beaches. Itrsquos very, very quiet where the golf course practice range is, so I went down there.ldquoAnd also the harbour, for lots of the clinking and clanking of sails and at the jetty down by the harbour when the tide was at its highest. I put a load of microphones and left them there as well.With more than  hoursrsquo worth of sounds, Ted used recordings he had made in erse places, including the Amazon rainforest, Rajasthan in India, and Norway.For those places he was unable to get to, such as Antarctica, Ted recreated the noises he imagined would be heard using his own instruments and accessories. For Antarctica, he recorded harsh winds and tents flapping, ice chunks moving around a bath, and also penguins at the zoo.But he was moved toto North Berwick last year for the Europe album.He said: ldquoItrsquos my interpretation of what I think the world sounds like some people will agree, some people wonrsquot.ldquoItrsquos my musical sound diary, so to speak and for the Europe album there were places that I felt connected to, so I recorded a lot in the Highlands, around Aberfeldy, in the winter, to get those blustery sounds, and a lot around North Berwick because thatrsquos where I grew up and, to be honest, when yoursquore trying to capture sounds itrsquos so dficult to find places which have not a lot of noise pollution, and North Berwick in the night for some reason is not that loud.The Mindfulness Nature albums can be found online at sites including Apple Music and Spoty.

title: musselburgh-churches-helping-food-donations-pandemic
story: Musselburgh Baptist Church opens its foodbank every Thursday morning between am and noon, while St Andrewrsquos High Church members have been helping out East Lothian Foodbank.Ross McNab, assistant pastor at the baptist church, said it was ldquoamazing that the congregation was back together meeting in person since the end of March, adding that the church wanted to extend ldquoa warm welcome to our wider community to come join us.He added: ldquoWe are meeting together every Sunday and currently hold three services at am, .am and noon. Each service lasts approximately one hour and contains a mixture of music, teaching and prayer.ldquoTo help us follow current guidelines and maintain a safe environment, booking is required. To book a seat, please get in touch via info@musselburghbaptist.org or message us through our Facebook page , where we also livestream our .am service.The Rev Dr Leslie Milton, minister at St Andrewrsquos High Church, said: ldquoWe have had a particular focus on supporting East Lothian Foodbank throughout the pandemic and members were active in Resilient Musselburgh while it was operating.ldquoOur morning worship is at am in church and on Facebook. We hold an additional service on a Tuesday afternoon once a month for those who are unable to come out in the morning.ldquoWe have a weekly coffee morning and occasional discussion groups on Zoom. We are now livestreaming the services. We are also able through Facebook and the weekly email to include people who find it hard to get to church. The weekly email with the full service and the livestream services will continue even after all restrictions are lted.ldquoWe are surprised and delighted by the way many older people have embraced technology and social media.

title: bins-possible-haddington-skatepark-complaint-overflowing-bin-spoilt-facility
story: The skate park, on the townrsquos Whittingehame Drive, has proven increasingly popular with youngsters.Ian Clark contacted the Courier and said he had spent a day supervising his grandchildren at the facility.But, he said, it was ldquospoilt by an overflowing litter bin which either has not been emptied recently or is totally inappropriate for the volume of rubbish created by the large number of youngsters using this excellent facility.Mr Clark noted there were youngsters using the nearby football pitch who had tried to dispose of empty bottles of water but were unable to fit them in the bin.He added: ldquoIt was blowing about and kids were wanting to put stuff in the bin but they could not.He called on East Lothian Council to provide more bins to ensure litter was disposed of appropriately.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoThere are a number of bins in and around the vicinity of Whittingehame Drive that people can use for disposing of their personal litter.ldquoIt is encouraging to see the skate facility being so well used and we are grateful for this feedback and will consider the location, size and amount of bins in the location highlighted.

title: cautions-drivers-caught-haddington-without-valid-mot-certificates
story: Police highlighted the incidents in a report to Haddingtonrsquos community council on April .The first incident took place on the townrsquos Florabank Road on March , with a second vehicle stopped two days later at the townrsquos Abbotsview Junction.On both occasions, the driver was cautioned and charged and a conditional offer issued.

title: royal-seal-approval-given-haddington-business-puremalt
story: Haddingtonrsquos PureMalt Products Ltd is one of  organisations across the UK to receive the Queenrsquos Award for Enterprise this year.The family business was established in  by the Turner family and produces natural ingredients for the global food and beverage industries.The good news was revealed last Thursday, with PureMalt, which employs nearly  people, specically recognised for its excellence in international trade, distributing products to more than  countries globally.Bruce Turner MBE, chairman and managing director of the business off Haddingtonrsquos Whittingehame Drive, paid tribute to the workforce.He said: ldquoWe are humbled to be honoured with this prestigious award.ldquoCompeting in global markets requires high levels of competency in all s of the business.ldquoIt is wonderful recognition for the talented efforts of our team, without whom this accolade would not have been possible.ldquoI am very proud of the wider PureMalt family today!Last week saw the businessrsquos historic building restored to its former glory, when a copper pagoda was craned into place on top of the premises.The previous pagoda was damaged during a roof fire in May .Now in its th year, the Queenrsquos Awards for Enterprise are the most prestigious business awards in the country, with winning businesses able to use the esteemed Queenrsquos Awards emblem for the next five years.Applications for Queenrsquos Awards for Enterprise  opened on Saturday.

title: north-berwicks-coastal-communities-museum-reopens-first-time-year
story: Similar to other venues, it closed last year due to coronavirus but decided to remain closed for the rest of the season.But now the museumrsquos board and volunteers have welcomed back visitors for the first time on Saturday.The museum on School Road will be open am-pm every Thursday, Friday and Saturday, and also on bank holidays, throughout the summer.A limited number of visitors are allowed at any one time, with a booking system now in place. Bookings can be made by calling   or emailing book ings@coastalmuseum.orgAnd one of the new exhibits touches on the Covid pandemic.It is a special cover quilt produced by the Law Quilters, commemorating the townrsquos community response to the pandemic.Produced during the resilience effort last year, the lockdown memory quilt was produced by the grouprsquos  members and consists of a number of dferent images to commemorate the community response to the pandemic...including the panic buying of toilet roll!The group, founded in , also made quilts for hospitals, hospices and womenrsquos refuges, as well as linus quilts for children, cushions for mastectomy patients, face coverings and quilts for incubators.Alongside the quilt will be last yearrsquos exhibition.Last year was the Year of Coasts and Waters, which was extended into this year due to the pandemic.Called lsquoWish You Were Herersquo, the exhibition focuses on seaside postcards, particularly those by local artist R P Phillimore.The exhibition also explores the history of North Berwick.The museum is run by volunteers in partnership with East Lothian Council.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-host-first-ever-marine-festival
story: The conservation and education charity, which has now reopened to the public, will see its two-week Marine Fest kick off on May , with a programme of events including workshops, live science shows, rockpool rambles, bird identication walks, beach cleans, puppet shows and sand sculpting.Susan Davies, Scottish Seabird Centre chief executive, said: ldquoAs climate change warms our oceans and threatens the basis of all le, our conservation and education work is now more important than ever.ldquoThe climate crisis is one of the most challenging issues to address but there are steps everyone can take inidually, or in our communities, that can help reduce the overall pressures on our marine environment and seabirds.ldquoAt the Scottish Seabird Centre, we help people to understand some of the things they can do to address this, we explain marine science, prompt ideas and motivate people to make their own behavioural changes in response to the climate crisis.The new festival, supported by EventScotland as part of the Year of Coasts and Waters   and Scotlandrsquos Events Recovery Fund, will enable visitors to learn more about Scotlandrsquos seas and the challenges they face, especially the climate emergency.Susan added: ldquoOur Marine Fest programme of activities should provide something for members of the local community and visitors to enjoy. We would like to thank EventScotland for their support through Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters, which has allowed us to create this new festival.Paul Bush OBE, director of events at VisitScotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to support Marine Fest as part of the Year of Coasts and Waters  .ldquoScotland offers the perfect stage to explore our natural environment and this yearrsquos festival will combine live and digital events to showcase and celebrate the countryrsquos marine environment and wildle.The Scottish Seabird Centre is now open daily and its Marine Fest will run from May  to June .For more information, visit seabird.org

title: north-berwick-lifeboat-crew-saved-three-lives-last-year-figures-reveal
story: Newly revealed statistics show the crew spent  hours last year on callouts, a third of which were in hours of darkness. In total, it launched its D-Class leboat  times.Due to the coronavirus pandemic last year, fundraising events were cancelled, RNLI shops closed and training curtailed, but it did not stop the crew responding to help those in dficulty at sea.The types of call the crew attended ied but the majority were in the summer months to those using the sea for leisure activities such as swimming, stand-up paddleboarding or kayaking.A number of swimmers were also rescued from rip currents, with two lives saved and many other incidents being close to a serious outcome.Rhona Meikle, leboat helm, said: ldquoWe know from second-hand accounts that other people were caught out by rip currents and waves last year but didnrsquot know what a rip current was, how to get themselves out of dficulty or, worryingly, to dial  and ask for the coastguard.ldquoWe urge everyone to visit the RNLI website and check out the beach safety pages for vital lesaving information.With lockdown restrictions beginning to ease once more and a large number of people expected to book a lsquostaycationrsquo, the RNLI expects this summer to be its busiest yet, with more funds needed to help it continue its work.In preparation for this busy period, the RNLI has launched its own Mayday campaign and is asking people to take part in The Mayday Mile. For more information, visit rnli.org mayday

title: pictures-kiltwalkers-america-germany-help-boost-north-berwick-charity
story: On April , supporters and members of Stepping Out, based in North Berwick, took part in the virtual Kiltwalk event to raise funds for the project.The Kiltwalk sees people take part in the walking challenge and raise money for Scottish charities in the process.Due to the coronavirus pandemic, this yearrsquos event took place virtually.But it was not just in East Lothian that people were taking part.Walkers and cyclists grabbed some tartan and took part, with some even helping raise money for the charity in Germany and New York.The virtual Kiltwalk event enabled the charityrsquos members, who would not take part in a mass event, to participate, contribute and enjoy being part of the experience.There was not one set route for supporting Stepping Out, with participants instead walking ious routes according to inidual ability.Most of the East Lothian walkers followed parts of the John Muir Way.The projectrsquos community mental health team walked from North Berwick to Dunbar, a total distance of  miles.Stepping Out staff member Ann Richardson and her daughter Meg walked from Haddington to Longniddry, where they enjoyed a vegan cookie, and then travelled on to North Berwick, also a total distance of  miles.Some members took on a half-marathon distance, which saw them get the train to Longniddry and walk back to North Berwick, while others with limited mobility challenged themselves with a walk around the Lodge Grounds or the -kilometre route to the lake at the Balgone Estate, to the south of North Berwick.Not everyone walked during the challenge, with some of those taking part cycling instead, with support from Cycling UK, which helps people back into cycling, getting onto bikes for the first time in years.Prior to the challenge, those who cycled for it gradually built up their skills and confidence on a bike, with the Kiltwalk challenge their first outing since lockdown.They completed a round trip from Aberlady to North Berwick, a total of  miles.Nicky Fox, Stepping Outrsquos project manager, who has been undergoing treatment for kidney cancer for the last two years, also got on her bike and joined the cycling group, having also not been on a bicycle for about  years.In Germany, Nikolai, his dad Frank and one-year-old son Tavis completed a -kilometre walk beside the River Hamme, near Bremen in north-west Germany.In New York, Jean Matthews walked with her granddaughter and six other family members and friends, taking in the views of the city as they went.The total amount of money raised is expected to smash last yearrsquos figure of pound,, but the final amount has not yet been calculated.A spokesperson for the charity said: ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who has taken part and everyone who has donated.

title: torness-power-station-outage-complete-14-000-pieces-work-finished
story: Reactor  at the EDF-operated nuclear power station has ed to service following a pound million investment programme, which took place over the course of three months.A number of important projects were successfully completed, including the replacement of the low-pressure turbine rotor, turbine valve inspections and detailed inspections of the graphite core.At its peak, more than  people were present on site including visiting contractors.Despite this, both industrial and Covid- safety were maintained.Tam Albishawi, station director at the power station to the east of Dunbar, was pleased with how the outage had gone.He said: ldquoOutages are always planned scrupulously to ensure they run well and we took the same approach to managing Covid during an outage.ldquoAs well as putting in place a strict testing regime, we ensured the enforcement of social distancing, regular hand washing and mandatory mask wearing on site.ldquoI am glad that the measures we put in place kept rates so low, keeping people on site and in the community safe.ldquoIn addition to tackling the usual big maintenance projects, the team have also inspected the reactorrsquos graphite core as part on an ongoing inspection programme happening at each of our stations and these checks have confirmed that all is as expected.ldquoEveryone involved worked really hard to make sure we were able to deliver one of our best ever outages and I am delighted that the unit is back online and helping Britain achieve net zero.Covid was a particular focus of the outage, which had been postponed from summer last year to allow for better arrangements to be introduced nationally and at the site.EDF acted early to introduce ldquostringent protective measures including social distancing, mandatory face masks, thermographic cameras and working from home, where possible, which helped keep on-site rates consistently low.The company also invested in mass testing capability and required visiting contractors to register a negative test before entering the site, as well as at least weekly testing for all those working there.A spokeswoman for EDF said: ldquoOver the -week outage period, we carried out almost , tests and recorded  Covid positive cases.ldquoAlmost all of these cases were asymptomatic and detected due to the rigorous testing regime put in place by EDF to protect those on site and in the wider community.ldquoThe ability to identy these cases meant that workers were able to immediately self-isolate while close contacts were traced and asked not to come to site. All cases were reported to public health authorities.The outage, which got under way in January, also boosted the local economy, with a number of the key workers staying in local hotels.Last year, Torness generated enough low-carbon electricity to power . million homes more than the number of households in Scotland.The station employs more than  full-time staff and about  full-time contract partners to ensure the safe reliable generation of electricity.

title: call-donate-carrier-bags-faside-community-pantry
story: Volunteer Centre East Lothian is based on the townrsquos High Street and is home to Farsquoside Community Pantry.The pantry is open Mondays-Fridays, am-pm.While all donations are gratefully accepted, it is on the lookout for carrier bags which will be used to hand out items to the iniduals and families it helps.Pre-made bags are handed out at the centre door as visitors are not able to enter the building due to coronavirus restrictions. For more information, call  .There have also been some donations from local groups to the pantry.Two boxes of childrenrsquos clothes were donated by Dougie Fergie on behalf of the Provincial Grand Lodge of East Lothian, and staff at Bridge Dental Care in Tranent donated several boxes of toothpaste.

title: ferret-jumped-car-tranent-cemetery-reunited-owner
story: The Scottish SPCA had appealed for the owner to come forward after the animal was found in Tranent Cemetery on April  and jumped into ldquoan unsuspecting member of the publicrsquos car.A spokeswoman for the charity confirmed that the light-coloured ferret, which was taken to the Scottish SPCArsquos Edinburgh centre, had now been reunited with his owner.

title: wedding-in-the-woods-photo-taken-near-tyninghame-picked-one-worlds-best-top-competition
story: Amanda Farnese Heath was highly commended in the Champagne Taittinger Wedding Food Photographer category at the Pink Lady Food Photographer of the Year awards with Wild Wedding For Two.The picture was shot in woods near Tyninghame and Amanda was delighted with the success.She said: ldquoIt was taken during the summer of the first lockdown, around about July.ldquoIt was basically, with the permission of the Forestry Commission, taken deep in the forest near Tyninghame.ldquoIt was a place that we went and found because of the light and everything  that was good for a photograph.Amanda, who lives near Seaclf, has been a photographer for nearly  years and also devotes her time to The Mad March Hare, which offers a dining experience with a dference.The business offers people the chance to enjoy dinner in a number of unusual places, such as deep in the woodland.The photographer, who has previously worked as a stylist with companies including Dobbies Garden Centres and Edinburgh Preserves, said: ldquoI came up with the idea of offering anyone wishing to get married during lockdown a wild tiny wedding with an exquisite banquet in a remote secret location in Scotland.ldquoThis is one of the images from our first minuscule event.The picture was set so that the bride, a model from Glasgow, would be wandering through the forest before coming across the table.Amanda, , spoke to the Courier while she was in the Highlands ldquoon a recce as she prepares her photograph for next yearrsquos awards.The winners of this yearrsquos awards were announced by Fred Sirieix, of First Dates, in an awards ceremony that was live streamed on the competitionrsquos YouTube channel at the end of last month, with people tuning in from across the globe.ldquoOn the competitionrsquos th anniversary, it is wonderful that a record number of entries were received, said Phil Turnbull, CEO of APAL, owner of Pink Lady, and headline sponsor of the awards since .ldquoAlmost , entries were submitted from over  countries around the world.ldquoAs the reach of the competition grows further, it continues to be a truly global inspiration and celebration of the art of food photography.This yearrsquos global judging , chaired by legendary food photographer David Loftus, included Fiona Shields, head of photography,News  Media Nik Sharma, cookbook author and photographer chef Simone Zanoni, Restaurant Le George, Four Seasons Paris Alison Jacques, founder of Alison Jacques Gallery and Vitalie Taittinger, president of Champagne Taittinger.

title: saltoun-primary-school-pupils-represent-east-lothian-euroquiz-final
story: A team of P and P pupils from Saltoun Primary School came first in the Euroquiz heat and will now represent the county on June .Euroquiz is a yearly competition run by SEETfor P pupils from all over Scotland.It aims to widen the childrenrsquos knowledge of European geography, history, culture and languages.A spokeswoman for the primary school said: ldquoSaltoun Primary is a very small school with two multicomposite classes. The quiz is usually for P pupils but, because of our size, half of our team were from the younger age group of P.ldquoThe school staff are delighted with the teamrsquos hard work and dedication, and we are all very excited about the final.ldquoGo Team Saltoun!

title: putting-greens-reopen-start-next-month
story: enjoyleisure is ldquocurrently working towards reopening the seasonal facilities from June .That would see the -hole putting greens at North Berwickrsquos Quadrant and Elcho Green open, as well as two tennis courts off Quadrant.Meanwhile, in Musselburgh, it would mean the reopening of two grass bowling greens and a nine-hole pitch and putt course.

title: covid-scotland-rules-meeting-inside-home
story: All council areas in Scotlandare expected to move from level three to at leastlevel two from Monday, May .The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.These changes will mean that you will be allowed to meet indoors, including homes, as long as you stick to the restrictions.Heres what you need to know:The maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially in a home is fourwhich can be from twohouseholds, including for overnight stays.Children under the age of  do not count towards the total number of people or households meeting outside but do count towards household numbers indoorsChildren under  do not need to maintain physical distance from others.

title: binoculars-worth-2-500-found-bird-hide-musselburgh-lagoons
story: They were handed in to Musselburgh Police Station.If anyone has lost the binoculars, they should go to the police station with proof of ownershipavailable.

title: covid-scotland-can-level-2-lockdown
story: The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK have said the threat level should be lowered from "level "to "level ", thanks to the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Here is what you can and cannot do in Level  lockdown:Yes but the maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis six which can be from three households, including for overnight stays.Social distancing rules do not need to be followed.Yes. Indoors it will be sixadults from threehouseholds in an indoor public place like a cafeacute, pub or restaurant.Outdoors eight peoplefrom eight households will be allowed.Under s do not count towards the total number of people or households meeting outside but do count towards household numbers indoors.Yes, all non-essential shops will be open for business so you will be able to head to your favourite retailers.Yes, you will be able to travel anywhere across Scotland and the UK.However, as lockdown levels change, people in Level must not enter Levels - or Level  area unless for a permitted reason.Staycations will be permitted with travel restrictions lted and tourist accommodation will reopen.However, socialising rules must still apply.International travel is also allowed in  green list areas.It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on May .Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Yes, restaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars can open indoors until : with two-hour pre-booked slots.They can open outdoors within local licensing conditions for the consumption of food and alcoholic drinks.The maximum number of people you can meet indoors in a restaurant, cafeacute, pub or bar is sixwhich can be from up to threeseparate households.The maximum number of people you can meet outdoors in a restaurant, cafeacute, pub or bar is eightwhich can be from up to eight separate households.Takeaway service will also continue to be open.Yes, gyms and indoor sports facilities including swimming pools and leisure centres will be open for inidual exercise.Personal training and coaching are also permitted,Group activity will be permitted for under s.Yes, all organised outdoor sports are allowed provided appropriate safety measures are followed.Indoor contact sports are not permitted, except for professional sport.Yes, small seated indoor events are permitted with a maximum of  people. This includes theatres, bingo halls,music venues, comedy clubs,amusement arcades and casinos.Guidance is being produced which may allow higher capacities to be agreed with the local authority Scottish Government depending on the event.Yes, groups ofeight peoplefrom eight households will be allowed.It is worth noting that under s do not count towards restricted numbers or households outdoors.Yes.Outdoor seated and open space events are advised to operate with a maximum capacity of  people.Outdoor grouped standing events are advised to operate with a maximum capacity of  people.Small seated indoor events are advised to operate with a maximum of  people.You should continue to active travelwhere possible and avoid car sharing with people outside of your extended household.Face coverings compulsory on public transport and, due to limited capacity,you are using public transport then plan ahead.Nurseries, childminders and regulated school-age childcare providers are open with standard protective measures are in place.Informal childcare such as family and friendsare permitted.Yes, but it will be subject to guidance.Yes, all visitors centres can reopen for business.You are encouraged to work from home where possible.Yes, but the recommended family support from at least onevisitor per patient.Yes, however, the recommended minimum of twovisits per week, one person at a time.Yes, but it willbeblended learning.Yes, and  people are allowed to attend the ceremony and thewedding reception.Alcohol is also permitted.A maximum of  people are allowed to attend a funeral service and alcohol is permitted.Yes, places of worship will be open.Yes, public buildings such as libraries or community centres will be open.Some public buildings will operate an online booking system and some may have dedicated opening times for high-risk groupsYes, driving lessons are allowed.Work, such as home decorating, repairs etc areallowed indoors.Yes, you are allowed to move home.Yes, all close contact services, including mobile, may operate providing they follow Scottish Government guidance to ensure the safety of customers and staff.

title: glasgow-science-centre-free-attend-innovation-event
story: Curious About Innovation will celebrate the innovative spirit in all of us, and how that spirit can change the world.The three-day programme of live talks, interviews, games and resources will reveal how technology and innovation are solving global challenges. The festival is being delivered with support from the Inspiring Science Fund provided by Wellcome, UKRI and BEIS with additional support from JP Morgan, Mathworks and University of Strathclyde.Top innovators from Scotland and around the world have signed up to take part. Experts from organisations like Rolls Royce, AAC Clyde Space, the National Oceanographic Centre, IBM and the Scottish Space School have all signed up.NASA astronauts and engineers will be beamed in from the USA to answer questions about le in space the Royal Navy will take everyone on a guided tour round a virtual submarine and the plans to get oysters cleaning the Clyde will be revealed.The festival is free and open to everyone, just register on https:curiousabout.glasgowsciencecentre.org .Click image to attend for freeStephen Breslin, chief executive of Glasgow Science Centre, said: ldquoCurious About Innovation has been designed to entertain and inspire everyone aged  and upwards.ldquoSome of the worldrsquos most exciting science and technology will be showcased in the festival. It will cover industries like space, construction, cyber security, health, robotics and the environment.ldquoThe festival will inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers by highlighting the career paths and employers that are available to young people in Scotland.Curious About Innovation is Glasgow Science Centrersquos second online festival. It builds on the themes connected with GSCrsquos IdeaNo exhibition, which everyone can visit in person when the science centre reopens.The festival also supports GSC Learning Labrsquos space module and GSCrsquos STEM Futuresrsquo programme, which is helping thousands of young people into STEM work experience and career choices.Curious About Innovation is free to everyone, but those aged  and upwards will get the most out of it. Visit https:curiousabout.glasgowsciencecentre.org  for updates.Click image to attend for freeCurious About Innovation: HighlightsScotlandrsquos innovation in the space sector ,  May, -The space sector is booming in Scotland. Join AAC Clyde Space to find out about innovation and growth in the space sector and how we use satellites to communicate and collect information.NASA live talks,  May,    May, Join NASA engineers and astronauts as they give you the lowdown on living in space, and keeping astronauts comfortable and safe on orbit. Youll even have the opportunity to ask questions about their exciting careers.Virtual Submarine Tour with the Royal Navy,  May,  ndash Take a virtual tour of a Navy submarine, go behind the scenes and learn about the innovations and the practical engineering solutions within the vessel.Construction Innovation with Morrison Construction,  May,  ndash Take a virtual tour of a construction site, see how Morrison Construction uses the latest innovation and technology to design buildings on their sites. Hear how they use advanced low-energy construction to build sites with very low environmental impact.Jet Engine Evolution with Rolls Royce,  May ndash  ndash Take a virtual tour of the Rolls Royce site at Inchinnan! Go behind the scenes on the manufacturing journey to see how compressor aerofoils are made from beginning to end and understand theirwithin the jet engine. This workshop will also follow the evolution of the jet engine and how it has developed over the years to incorporate innovation as technology advances.Glasgow Tower Uncovered ndash Ideas StudioTake a tour of Glasgow Tower, an unique structure in Glasgow citys skyline. Get behind the scenes as we discuss some of the challenges it has faced, and the innovative solutions making this tower a Guinness World Record holder.Click image to join us for free

title: covid-hugs-drinking-pubs-resume-monday
story: And pubs will be allowed to sell alcohol indoors from Monday too, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed today.Mainland Scotland will move to level two restrictions - although Moray is set to remain in level three after a surge in cases.And a traffic light system will be introduced for international travel from Monday.Under the level two restrictions, up to six people from three households will be able to meet in their homes, and can also stay overnight.: Seven things to take away from Nicola Sturgeons updateAlcohol can be served indoors in pubs or restaurants, which will be allowed to stay open until .pm. Up to six adults from three households will be able to meet indoors in a public place.Restrictions on meeting up outdoors will ease further, enabling up to eight adults from eight dferent households to gather.Adult outdoor contact sports and indoor group exercises will be able to resume.Cinemas, bingo halls and amusement arcades are also likely to be able to reopen.

title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update-covid-rules-set-ease
story: People in Scotland will be able to hugged loved ones again from Monday ndash subject to restrictions ndash an emotional Nicola Sturgeon has said as she confirmed further lockdown easing.These changes will include meeting up to six people from three households socialising indoors, restaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars openingindoors until :, and cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls reopening and, quarantine-free international travel.It comes after the Covid- alert level in the UK was downgraded from Level  to Level  after a "consistent"fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK put it downto the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.Heres what you need to know:The First Minister confirmed that the majority of Scotland will move to Level  lockdown from May .Moray will stay in Level and the Scottish Islands will move to Level  from Monday.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Household changesThe maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis six people which can be from three households, including for overnight stays.Hugs are back!Nicola Sturgeon has confirmed that hugs will be allowed indoors in Scotland.The First Minister said: "From Monday,you are meeting friends and family, within the permitted limits of course, either indoors in a private dwelling or in your garden, our guidance will say that it is no longer necessary to maintain physical distance."Which means - and I actually feel a bit emotional as I say this - that from Monday, as long as you stay within permitted limits, you can hug your loved ones again."I know how desperate we all are for this - and so I donrsquot intend to immediately pour cold water on it - but there are two further points I really need to make."She added: "Close physical contact does still carry risk, I have to be clear about that."Soyou have loved ones who are vulnerable for any reason, please still be careful. And limit the overall number of people that you choose to have close physical contact with."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that Moray will not move to Level  and will stay in Level  for a "further period".The decision comes as health authorities in the area are currently dealing with "uncontrolled, sustained community transmission"of Covid-, with current restrictions failing to contain the spread.Latest statistics show Moray had . cases per , people in the seven days to May , signicantly higher than the rate in the rest of Scotland.Travel restrictions willbe brought into Moray and people should only enter there for essential purposes only.Ms Sturgeon said: "In recent days, as you will have seen, Moray has been experiencing a high and increasing number of cases with a small associated increase in hospital admissions."Indeed, public health experts consider that Moray is currently experiencing widespread community transmission."She added: "It is therefore highly probable that Moray will stay at level  for a further period."It is also important that we take precautions to reduce the risk of the transmission of Covid spreading from Moray to other parts of Scotland, as restrictions ease where.""SoMoray does stay in level  - which will be finally decided at the end of the week - we will also reimpose travel restrictions for a hopefully short period.This will mean that travel in and out of Moray will be limited to permitted purposes only."Islands changesMany islands in Scotland will move to Level  due to low case numbers.Nicola Sturgeon said:"For our island communities, the situation is dferent and much more positive."Case numbers have consistently been at very low levels for some time now."Many islands also now have very good vaccination coverage, and lateral flow tests are available for all people travelling to the islands from other parts of Scotland."For those reasons, we have decided that it is possible to ease restrictions more quickly for communities in the Western Isles, Shetland and Orkney for all islands in Highland, except Skye, given its fixed link and for the Inner Hebrides islands in Argyll - including Islay, Jura and Mull."All of these areas will move directly to level  from Monday, rather than to level ."International TravelPeople in Scotland will be able to travel to some foreign destinations without the need to quarantine on their .It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on May .Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Nicola Sturgeon said: "At the outset, let me be very clear that we still intend to be highly cautious on international travel - given the risk of new iants - but we consider that the situation now allows us to begin a careful move away from blanket restrictions on non-essential travel."From Monday, we will move to a traffic light system, informed by risk assessments prepared by the Joint Biosecurity Centre. These assessments will be based on the state of the pandemic in each country across the world - including the presence of iants of concern."These green countries include:The First Minister was unable to update on the latest Covid numbers due to "IT issues".Nicola Sturgeon said:"I hope that will be resolved soon, and I can assure you that all of todays figures will be published just as quickly as possible."Youll be able to access them when theyre published on the Scottish Government website."

title: spectators-welcomed-back-musselburgh-racecourse-later-month
story: In a carefully managed event, the East Lothian track will admit  racing fans in the first steps towards lting Covid- restrictions and resuming normal racing.The racecourse has worked closely with the East Lothian Safety Advisory Group to establishing a raceday protocol, which can be amended as further restrictions are relaxed in the weeks ahead.At the afternoon meeting on May , alcohol and food can only be ordered and must be consumed at tables in a designated picnic area, while a two-metre distancing rule will be enforced throughout the course.The racecourse has also confirmed that its popular Stobo Castle Ladies Day has been moved from August  to Friday, August , to maximise the enhanced safety benefits from the Governmentrsquos objective of having every adult vaccinated by the end of July.A crowd limit for what is traditionally a sell-out event will be set once it becomes clear what restrictions, , any might be in place in August.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, said: ldquoIt has been a very challenging year for Musselburgh and all Scottish racecourses, and while our instinct is to welcome back as many racing fans as possible, we are erring on the side of caution by opting to admit only  visitors are our next meeting.ldquoThe measures we have put in place underline that the safety of our guests, racing industry personnel and our staff must come first, but we will use the meeting on May  as a template for going forward.ldquoNo doubt we will learn what works best for hosting a race day for the general public against the backdrop of Covid- restrictions."We are confident we can offer an entertaining afternoon of live sport with ample space around the course to allow visitors to socially distance.Mr Farnworth stressed that no bars or restaurants would be open and that food and alcohol would only be served at a designated seated picnic area. Visitors will not be allowed to enter the grounds with their own picnics.He added: ldquoMoving Stobo Castle Ladies Day to August  is simply to give us the best chance of hosting our most popular race meeting in a more relaxed environment, and given that most people should by then have received their vaccinations, this should add an extra layer of comfort for racegoers.Guests who have already booked Ladies Day admission tickets for August  have been informed of the change of date and been issued refunds, and they will prioritised when rebooking for the August  event.In June, Musselburgh hosts three racedays, including The Edinburgh Cup Raceday on Saturday, June , two afternoon meetings in July, and in August a further four meetings, including Stobo Castle Ladies Day. The racecourse will release details for these fixture as the relaxation of Covid regulations develops.Tickets for the race meetings on May  and June  go on sale on Thursday at am and are expected to sell out quickly.For a full fixture list and to book tickets, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: musselburgh-north-berwick-swimming-pools-open-week
story: enjoyleisure, which runs the facilities on behalf of East Lothian Council, said that both pools were fitted with brand new booms and floating floors at the end of .Work continued on the pool upgrades during lockdown, although at a much more restrictive pace due to Covid- restrictions.A spokesperson for enjoyleisure said: "The delay in reopening was due to signicant snagging and safety concerns. We did not want to put any of our customers at any potential risk. We fully appreciate the delay caused considerable frustration and we too were just as eager to open these facilities."Further work on the booms is still required to make them fully operational. Meantime, the floating floors have been secured at a depth of . metres and we can now reopen the pools for public swimming. Please note, at this depth, ing is not permitted and aqua classes swimming lessons will take place from the shallow end of the pool."Unfortunately, a further period of closure, at some future date, will be necessary to make the floors and boom fully al. Engineers are working up their plans and ordering the necessary materials to complete this work, along with organising specialist sub-contractors. We will keep all our customers updated as and when we have further details of this work."We would like to express our sincere thanks for our customers patience and understanding regarding the reopening of the swimming pools at Musselburgh and North Berwick."Participants in swimming lessons have been contacted regarding the resumption of lessons from Friday. If you have any queries about swimming lessons, email swimming@enjoyleisureBookings for public swim sessions, lane swim sessions, childrens fun activities and AquaFit classes will open on Thursday at am. Call   for more details.

title: jumping-joy-fitness-classes-sports-centres-east-lothian-resume-monday
story: Participants must book prior to attending any class, this can be done online or by calling the inidual sports centre.Classes will not be able to be booked this weekend due to IT disruption but telephone enquiries can still continue and payments made in person by cash only.As well as in-person classes, a number of will also continue to be run via Zoom.And also, swimming pools in North Berwick and Musselburgh are to reopen on Friday.SEE MORE: Musselburgh and North Berwick swimming pools to open this weekenjoyleisure has said it will be continuingly monitoring all fitness classes on a regular basis and modying and adapting the timetable in line with demand.Bill Axon,enjoyleisure chief executive, said:ldquoTuesdayrsquos Scottish Government announcement confirming a move to Level  from Monday , is brilliant news for our many customers who attend coached classes and is greatly welcomed by everyone atenjoyleisure."The resumption of group exercise albeit socially distanced, is a massive boost to our customers and coaches alike who like many others have been furloughed since Boxing Day. "enjoyrsquosfitness coaches are eager to , and we canrsquot wait to have our halls and studios buzzing with excitement as adults of all agesfor their endorphin releasing boost! Friendships are created out ofshared interests, motivation levels are enhanced by engaging instructors."For many, itrsquos an opportunity for quality me time to energise, relax or de-stress. title: man-reported-haddington-pedlars-act
story: The incident was highlighted in a written report to the townrsquos community council, which met on Tuesdayevening.Regarding the incident on April , the report said: ldquoA male was reported for behaving in a threatening and abusive manner and an offence under the Pedlars Act, after attending a number of addresses in Haddington.

title: covid-recovery-first-focus-says-new-east-lothian-msp-paul-mclennan
story: Paul McLennan won the county seat for the SNP as he defeated Labourrsquos Martin Whitfield, the Conservativesrsquo Craig Hoy ndash both of whom are now South Scotland MSPs ndash and Euan Davidson of the Liberal Democrats.MSPs are sworn in at the Scottish Parliament today , with Mr McLennan ndash who has risen through the ranks from community councillor in Dunbar to former East Lothian Council leader to MSP ndash keen to look to the future.Speaking on Tuesday morning, Mr McLennan, who is also a ward councillor for Dunbar and East Linton, said: ldquoI think for me, the whole focus for the next wee while is going to be Covid recovery.ldquoThere are three main areas for me, including economic recovery.ldquoThat has been good so far and I have got a real feel for where businesses are.ldquoI chaired the town centre group on the council and we have a meeting where we talk about tourism, the town centre and the general economic position. We do that every week and that is the key thing now: getting businesses open.ldquoTourism is a major part of that and there will be another announcement hopefully to see more reopening.ldquoWe have just got to try to support tourism, leisure, hospitality, town centres and the broader economic recovery.Mr McLennan, who is exploring how to donate his councillor salary to a local charity while an MSP, has already been in discussions with Lesley Brown, executive director of education and childrenrsquos services at East Lothian Council, about the educational recovery in the wake of the pandemic.He stressed that it was not just about the next six months or even a year but looking beyond that.Similarly, Mr McLennan, who lives in Dunbar with we Sharron, was keen to work with the NHS in its recovery.Labour had held the East Lothian seat since the Scottish Parliament was formed in , with John Home Robertson and then Iain Gray representing the county for more than  years.However, , people voted for Mr McLennan last Thursday, with Mr Whitfield finishing in second spot on ,.The victor told the Courier his phone had ldquonever stopped ringing with people congratulating him ahead of his first trip to Holyrood as a newly elected MSP.He said: ldquoIt felt a bit surreal but the overriding thing is it is incredibly humbling just thinking about the amount of support.ldquoI am really determined now with people putting faith in myself and the SNP it is up to me now to go and repay that faith.ldquoI am very proud of what we achieved and really looking forward to getting into the business of parliament.The election count was held on Friday at Meadowmill Sports Centre, near Tranent, with coronavirus restrictions in place.Mr McLennan, who plans to have a constituency office set up this summer, said he and the party were ldquocautiously optimistic as the day wore on but it was too close to call as to who would come out on top.The four candidates were then invited into a room and told the result before it was made public.Mr McLennan, who has lived in Dunbar all his le and previously worked with the Bank of Scotland on the townrsquos High Street, took time to thank those who had helped him during the campaign but also singled out someone who could not be there, his dad Jim, who died two years ago.He said: ldquoI could not drive until I was about  for ious reasons.ldquoMy dad used to drive me to surgeries and to meetings sometimes.ldquoHe died from dementia two years ago and in his last few years he could hardly talk but I remember he said: lsquoThatrsquos my son, he is a councillor.rsquoldquoWhen I was elected to East Lothian Council in , it meant so much to him and he was one of the first thoughts I had on Friday.ldquoI was thinking about my dad andhe had been there.Mr McLennan, who previously served on Dunbar Community Council, became a councillor in  when he was elected as one of three members of the Dunbar and East Linton
