title: ‘Disappointed’ by minister’s decision
story: LOCAL politicians have issued another invitation to Stormont Health Minister Robin Swann to discuss the future of hospital services in the district.Members of Newry, Mourne and Down Council expressed their disappointment that Mr Swann has refused to meet a council delegation to discuss future plans for the Downe and Daisy Hill hospitals.At last weekrsquos monthly meeting of the council there was unanimous agreement that the minister should be asked to think again.Rowallane area councillor Billy Walker set the tone by stating that he was ldquototally disappointed by Mr Swannrsquos decision. Even so, he was also at pains to point out that he was not attacking the minister.ldquoThere are numerous issues regarding the Downe and Daisy Hill that need to be dealt with face to face with the minister, he said.ldquoWe have engaged with health trusts until we are blue in the face and we are getting nowhere. We need to put it up to the minister. We are in unprecedented times.Downpatrick councillor Oonagh Hanlon said she too was disappointed and urged Mr Swann to reconsider.ldquoThis is such an important issue, she said. ldquoWe are coming out of Covid and we need the restoration of services at the Downe. I am very disappointed, she remarked.Fellow Downpatrick councillor Gareth Sharvin said he acknowledged that Mr Swann was under pressure, but suggested that a virtual meeting could easily be arranged.ldquoThe Downe Hospital is extremely important to the people I represent, he said. ldquoWe need the minister to come out and say he is as passionate about the Downe as we are.His SDLP colleague, John Trainor, said the council needed to ldquoexplore every avenue, adding that councillors should ask the Stormont Health Committee to interveneMr Swann was to refuse to meet then a second time.Rowallane councillor Kathryn Owen, who nursed in a Covid unit at the height of the pandemic, said she wished to ldquoput on record her disappointment.She added: Knowing how important these two hospitals are and having worked in them, it was a weak response..prettyPhoto

title: £45m investment needed to upgrade Ardglass harbour
story: INVESTMENT in the region of poundm is needed to upgrade Ardglass harbour to help maximise the portrsquos future opportunities, according to a major new report published on Monday.Stormont agriculture minister Edwin Poots has published the findings of the report which highlights the investment needed in Northern Irelandrsquos fishing industry and seafood sectors.The report was produced by the Fishing and Seafood Development Programmewhich was established by the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsto conduct a strategic review of the opportunities for developing the sea fishing and seafood sectors across the province, including the potential role of new public investment in infrastructure.Focusing on recommendations in relation to capital investment at the main fishery harbours, the report highlights a number of challenges and opportunities for the wider industry that could be addressed through a future fisheries financial support scheme.The recommendations for Ardglass include enhancing capacity at the harbour to provide security for fishing and processing businesses, while the development of Kilkeel harbour as a ldquopotential Irish Sea hub for the fishing and maritime economy by increasing port capacity and shore side facilities is highlighted.More generally, the detailed report highlights the need to create conditions resulting in investment in more modern fuel efficient vessels with low emissions and better facilities for crews, further reducing the environmental impact of the fishing fleet, adopting novel technology to expand marine aquaculture and taking advantage of EU exit opportunities to build exports of high value seafood.The report confirms that a recent survey of the harbour walls in Ardglass revealed that some repairs may be required within the next one to two years but their condition will not prevent the deepening of the harbour mdash to nine metres below the waterline mdashthey are stabilised and protected from undermining prior to dredging operations.It says the current water depth and quaysideprevents larger fishing vessels from landing at Ardglass with tankers transporting fish landed in Belfast to the village for processing. Mackerel and Irish Sea herring continue to be landed in Ardglass.The report says there is inadequate space for growing the inshore fleet at the port as the quayside is dominated by the larger demersal fleet and occasional visiting pelagic vessels, with the adjoining marina for the exclusive use of leisure craft.A constraint to the landside development of the harbourrsquos estate is the mixed ownership of existing properties which prevents the Fishery Harbour Authority from having full control over activities at the port and limits the ability to plan strategically.As a result, the Fishing and Seafood Development Programme proposes a poundm budget to purchase properties and prepare buildings and land within the harbour for redevelopment.With the cost of the work at the main harbour estimated at poundm, the report explains the figure can only be revised following the completion of a bathymetric survey.Ardglass councillor Dermot Curran said he was keen to meet with Mr Poots to discuss the detail of the report and the level of work required.ldquoThe report highlights the development of an lsquoIrish Sea hub in Kilkeel and I know that many in Ardglass will be keen to hear from the minister what exactly this means. Ardglass plays a critical role in the Co Down fishing industry and its contribution to this key sector must be expanded, he said.ldquoThere are two major processing factories in Ardglass and work to dredge the harbour to facilitate larger vessels is a critical component of the investment that is required.Cllr Curran said investment was required to meet the needs of the existing fleet and future vessels.He added: ldquoThe village fleet has increased over the years and those who work in the industry say while they are not necessarily expecting a huge increase in the number of boats, they do anticipate an increase in the quality of boats and for that to happen, the harbour must be fit for purpose.Mr Poots said he hoped the publication of the report ldquomarks the beginning of a new chapter in the history of the provincersquos fishing industry.ldquoThe report highlights the considerable investment that is required to help the industry adapt to the challenges it faces and grasp the opportunities presented following the United Kingdomrsquos exit from the EU, he explained.ldquoWe need to build a stronger and more resilient fishing and seafood industry that can adapt to change. Of course, this will not be easy but I hope that with government and industry working together we can build new infrastructure, become more prosperous, improve the marine environment and enhance our reputation as suppliers of quality sustainable seafood.Mr Poots said his department will be engaging with stakeholders to discuss the findings of the report over the next few weeks and hopes that the next phase of work towards harbour investment can proceed shortly.He also confirmed that later in the year DAERA will be consulting on plans for a future fisheries fund to address the wider needs of the fishing industry..prettyPhoto

title: Cara opens first ever Irish Roots festival
story: A CARRYDUFF schoolgirl was honoured at the weekend when she was asked to open the inaugural global Irish Roots online festival.Twelve year-old Cara Mailey is no stranger to appearing in television having appeared in several CBBC programmes over the last two years.However, on Sunday she became a storyteller for the festival which seeks to celebrate Irish people around the world with dferent skin colours.Along with Orla McKeating, the founder of Still I Rise Diversity Storytelling, Cara read two stories mdash Happy in Our Skin and I Am Whole.Both books celebrate dferent skin colours and celebrated the uniqueness of peoplesrsquo skin colours.Cara, who attends Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch, was born with achonlasia, a form of dwarfism.She also had the opportunity to share her story, what she likes about her skin and then she also talked about what it was like being dferent to other children her age.Orla also read a third book called the The Little Crayon, a childrenrsquos story book written by -year-old Amelia Kai, also from Belfast.The daughter of Tricia Mailey, a teacher at Cedar Integrated Primary School in Crossgar, Cara has a big personality and has appeared on CBBCrsquos Dengineers and Crafty Party.Tricia said: ldquoCara has read for Still I Rise now for about a year. I think they are amazing. As a teacher myself I think its great to have such books for children showing ersity.Cara inspired a new fashion range earlier this year for girls and teens born with the same condition as her.She hopes to be a spokesperson and campaigner for people with dwarfism in the future.The Irish Roots Festival, created by Tipperary native Lorraine Maher, finishes today.Speaking about the festival, she said: ldquoMixed-race people are one of the fastest growing demographics in the western world, it is crucial to highlight the lives, achievements and struggles of mixed-race Irish people.ldquoThis is a great opportunity to give a shout out globally to those of Irish ancestry regardless of colour or location, she said. ldquoRepresentation is so important for a sense of well-being and belonging..prettyPhoto

title: Developers invited to enter bids for redevelopment site
story: DEVELOPERS will be asked within the next few weeks to submit their respective bids for the redevelopment of the former Irish Street police base in Downpatrick.The news was confirmed at a meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee on Monday evening.Stretching back as far as St Patrickrsquos Avenue, the proposed development site includes the Irish Street car park and a number of empty buildings adjacent to the former police base.It is understood that five developers and  community groups have expressed an interest in the site with its regeneration being spearheaded by the Department for Communitiesand the local authorityThe development brief paves the way for the regeneration of the sprawling site and developers will be given up to  weeks to submit their respective proposals with a final assessment then made to select the preferred bidder who will be responsible for all planning and construction costs.Once a developer has been selected, the company will be given a year to secure planning approval and to complete the regeneration of the site within three years.Councillors were due to discuss a motion at Monday nightrsquos meeting which urged the council to acquire land to create a road access through the development site on to St Patrickrsquos Avenue as part of the redevelopment proposal and also upgrade and integrate three adjoining privately owned car parks into the proposal.Debate on the motion was adjourned, but in papers submitted prior to the committee meeting senior council staff made it clear that any change would result in the suspension of the development brief and changes to the projectrsquos business case.The local authority has been working on the Irish Street project in partnership with the DfC for some time and when the police base became available for sale, the local authority commissioned a feasibility study exploring options around how the site could be developed in tandem with the Irish Street car park.The study concluded that a so-called mixed use development of the sprawling site would be the most suitable option with the government department subsequently acquiring the land, with the local authority purchasing a strip of land between the Irish Street car park and the former police base.A project board was then set up comprising Downpatrick area councillors and a number of local stakeholders including business community representatives which sought the views of developers and the local community around the sitersquos potential uses and constraints.It was confirmed on Monday night that based on the feedback the development brief was worked up and will go to market in the coming weeks. Interested developers have already been informed of the pending opportunity to submit their proposals.Councillors were told that all of the work to date has focused on site access via current access routes from Market Street and Irish Street, with officials reaffirming that as part of the feasibility study, one option that was explored mdash but subsequently rejected mdash was providing a road access linking Irish Street with St Patrickrsquos Avenue.ldquoTo explore the purchase of additional lands at this stage would mean that the development brief process would have to be suspended and the business case revisited in line with land valuations, councillors were told.ldquoThe development brief has been drafted in such a way to allow developers to bring additional lands that they may choose to acquire to enhance their plans.The council paper added: ldquoAs part of the development brief, car parking provision will have to be demonstrated and how it is achieved will again be up to the innovation of bids brought forward. Car parking will be a key requirement in the assessment process and indeed planning approval process.Moving forward, there is an acknowledgement that the current Irish Street car park is badly laid out and that the redevelopment proposal provides an opportunity to address this, paving the way for it to be used for future events, markets and festivals, with the DfC and local council prepared to provide additional funding to allow this to happen.Signicantly, developers interested in the prime town centre site are being asked to focus on how their chosen scheme can potentially contribute to Downpatrickrsquos night-time economy post Covid, providing a boost for residents and help attract visitors to Downpatrick.As part of continuing work on the Irish Street revitalisation programme, graphics recently appeared on the front of the former police base, while the archway at the entrance to the Irish Street car park will be painted.Downpatrick councillors say they are acutely aware that the opportunity to redevelop a huge area of town centre land will not happen again, with the redevelopment plan having the potential to provide a boost for existing traders who have been at the heart of the town centre economy for decades..prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum thirds make historic league debut
story: SUNDAY was a momentous day in the history of Dundrum Cricket Club.For the first time the club have been able to enter a thirds team into league cricket and the Meadow was the venue as Dundrum took the field against Ards seconds with a team packed with experience and plenty of youth too.Dundrum captain Neil Reilly won the toss and elected to bat on a super wicket that the ground staff had prepared for the seconds the day before, but had not been used due to bad weather.In the first over, opener Eoin Moag nicked a gooddelivery which was caught frombehind by the Ards wicketkeeper,.This was followed in the second over by a Jack Calvert drive catching the edge of the bat and flying straight up to be caught, leaving Dundrum on  for .The tricky start was made worse when the captain was run out by a sharp piece of fielding from Ards, leaving the hosts on  for .This brought together a partnership between Keba Butler and Kristofer McNeill which finally found traction and started to produce a decent score.By the time Kristofer had been bowled for , the score had risen to  for  with some cracking shots by both batsman which on another day would have produced even more runs, but on a damp outfield restricted the number of fours.Andrew Hammond came in and produced a fast hitting nine to supplement Kebarsquos continued run chase which culminated in a not out score of  by the end of the allotted  overs.Ards came into bat and had a fast start, reaching  without loss after only three overs,.The captainrsquos second over proved to be a turning point in picking up two wickets for just a single run. This fired up Eoin Moag to produce another fine over and clean bowl A Lawther.Ards were now well on the back foot at  for . Captain Reilly took another wicket in the following over before handing the reins to Keba Butler, who promptly took a wicket with his fourth ball.Newcomer Matthew Douglas was introduced into the attack to replace Moag and was soon also among the wickets with only his fourth delivery for the club.This was followed up by Kristofer McNeill coming from behind the stumps to bowl mdash his two overs going for  runs, but also gaining wicket.With Dundrum now firmly in the driving seat, the bowling was passed around with youngsters Andrew Campbell and James Wright bowling well.Experienced clubmen Andrew Hammond and James Orr came on with James taking his first wicket of the season and Ardsrsquo last batsman to give Dundrum victory by  runs.A massive result for the club made possible by a dedicated ground staff, driven committee and some excellent work with young people in the surrounding area which has enabled the thirds to field five U- players, all of whom will be vying for a spot next week and maybe even the seconds..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 16%2C 2001
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash The project to transfer one of Ballynahinchrsquos most prestigious buildings was officially launched last week.The historic Market House in Ballynahinch is to get a new lease of le and over the coming months will be transformed into a new civic building during a near poundm redevelopment project.The scheme will complete the Ballynahinchrsquos Regeneration Committeersquos plans to transform the heart of the town and complement the redeveloped square.Local planning chiefs are expected to give the scheme the green light within the next few weeks and preliminary work to strip plaster from the building has revealed ornate stone work and archways which are to be incorporated in the design of the new civic facility.The chairman of the Regeneration Committee, Mr Vincent Fullam, said the public launch of the Market House project marks the end of a long crusade which involved numerous meetings.KILLYLEAGH ndash The future of a multi-million pound marina and housing project for Killyleagh is expected to be known next month.Local planning officials are expected to announcethey are prepared to allow the controversial scheme planned for the Gocean area in the town when they meet local politicians.Speculation is mounting the poundm plan will be refused, but planners have confirmed they have still not reached a final decision on the issue, explaining they are still heavily involved in discussions with a number of organisations.They say it would be wrong to draw any conclusion at this stage as the consultation process is far from complete.It had been widely predicted a public inquiry would be ordered into the project but after its detail was scrutinised by senior planners in Belfast, they passed it back to planners based at Rathkeltair House in Downpatrick and told them there would be no public scrutiny of the scheme.DUNDRUM mdash A call has been made for a review of planning in Dundrum before the beauty of the village is ldquolost forever.The request has been made by SDLP candidate, Mr Charlie McGrath, who says the pace of new housing developments in the area raises a number of issues which need to be addressed.Mr McGrath, a candidate in the Newcastle area, has said it will be too late for locals to complain about the shape of the area after the developers and planners had finished with the village. He has called for a debate into the problem ldquobefore itrsquos too late.Mr McGrath, who is also concerned about the lack of facilities for local residents, said he has written to the local banks about providing cash points and is ldquovery encouraged by the response. He is also pleased that replacement pubic toilets are again to be provided in the village.He said that with the influx of young families in the area there is a ldquoglaring need for youths facilities such as playgrounds and has commended the work of the Dundrum Forum for Play in raising the profile of what he called an ldquounderestimated need.DOWNPATRICK mdash The Great Hall at the Downshire Hospital will once again be filled with the sound of music next week when it is officially reopened after a major renovation programme.Over poundm has been invested in the regeneration project and the curtain goes up at next weekrsquos official opening in Downpatrick with a headline concert by the Ulster Orchestra.It makes a welcometo the county town for the prestigious event which marks the official public launch of the Great Hall project.The concert is just one of a series of events which have been pencilled into a packed programme of entertainment to mark the opening of what is being billed as a prestigious community facility following the extensive renovation programme.It is hoped that once the hall, which boasts state-of-the-art sound and lighting equipment, opens for business, it will be widely used for a number of events for patients, staff and local people.SAINTFIELD mdash A Rowallane area councillor has said the development of a town park in Saintfield is still at the top of his agenda.The DUPrsquos William Dick, who is seeking re-election when voters go to the polls next month, said the creation of a town park is already included in Down Councilrsquos capital development programme.But he wants to see it moved further up the list so people in the Saintfield and surrounding area can have use of the much-needed facility.Mr Dick has already identied a site he believes would be ideal and explained it does not feature in the development programmes of any local builders as it is unsuitable for housing.ldquoSaintfield is one of the fastest growing towns in Down District and it is vital future development is sustainable and managed in a sensitive way, he said.Mr Dick said thatre-elected, one of his main priorities will be to have the town park moved up the loa authorityrsquos capital programme.ldquoThe success of the scheme will depend on how much funding can be sourced for the town park and, compared with a number of capital projects the cash required for the Saintfield project is comparatively small.ARDGLASS mdash Just two Ardglass fishing boats will be taken out of servicea new decommissioning scheme goes ahead.Amid claims that the prawn fishing fleet is not being treated fairly under the new scheme, it has been claimed that just pound.m will be available to decommission prawn boats compared with pound.m for the white fleet boat.Fisherman have reacted angrily to the figures, primarily because they are over three times as many prawn boats fishing in the Irish Sea as white fish trawlers.The figures have been confirmed by local councillor, Mr Dermot Curran, following talks with fishermen in the village who catch one fth of the prawns landed annually in the Province.Mr Curran said while they agree with decommissioning, the fishermen have warned the process must be veriable and properly controlled.ldquoFishermen have a number of concerns and plan to raise these with Agriculture Minister Brid Rodgers during forthcoming talks at her Departmentrsquos headquarters in Belfast, said Mr Curran.CASTLEWELLAN mdash The decision to provide new nursery units at Castlewellan and Newcastle has been welcomed by South Down Assemblyman, Eamonn OrsquoNeill.Mr OrsquoNeill has welcomed news that St Malachyrsquos Primary School and St Maryrsquos Primary School have each been earmarked for new nursery schools.He said the announcement by the South Eastern Education and Library Board should be regarded as progress by many people who have called for more investment and commitment within the pre-school sector.ldquoI am delighted to see this additional, and very welcome addition, to our primary school provision, he said.ldquoNursery school education is seen by educationalists as a very important sector in the education of children.PORTAFERRY ndash Alliance Assembly member, Kieran McCarthy, has appealed to the Housing Executive and Association to give priority to local people waiting for houses in their own area.The politician, who is also a Portaferry councillor, made the call amid concerns that local people may be bypassed for new houses in favour of people from outside the town.He insisted that applicants from the area should be given priority where possible.Mr McCarthy said local people rightly expected to be housed in their own town..prettyPhoto

title: Glory for Gladiatorial
story: DOWNPATRICK Racecourse held the first of its two May meetings on Friday afternoon and while the meeting was low profile, it was a notable one for Spa nursing home owner and former local councillor William Brown.He had a welcome change of luck when his horse, Gladiatoral, trained at Draperstown by Noel Kelly and ridden by Coleraine jockey Jody McGarvey, won the opening Molson Coors Maiden Hurdle in fine style from Leac An Scail Lady, ridden by Grand National winner Rachael Blackmore, and Courting Flow. SP:  ,  ,  .In the Cosy Roof Handicap Hurdle Favori Logique and Conor Orr looked like winners racing to the post only for Michael OrsquoConnor to bring Centurion Steel with a run to snatch victory, with Lighthouse Rose back in third.OrsquoConnor likes the local track as this was his third success at the venue from only seven rides.The winner is trained in Waterford by Cheltenham and Aintree-winning trainer Henry De Bromhead.Cosy Roof also sponsored the handicap chase and here we had a gripping finish as Fly De Megaudais and Cathal Landers in front from thesecond last fence had to go all out to hold of the late bid of Carried in the colours of Co Armagh trainer Keith Watson.Carried was ridden by Armagh jockey Shane OrsquoCallaghan who has two winning rides to his credit, the first coming at Downpatrick when he was based in Co Monaghan with Anthony McCann, Downthecellar and Darragh OrsquoKeefe took third.The   winner is trained in Co Clare by Michael McDonagh. It was Landers first Downpatrick success.In the ITBA Supporting Northern Breeders Mares Handicap Hurdle long time back marker Shopping Around was brought with a well timed run by KeithDonoghue to win from Highstreet Roller and Dreamandhoping.The winner is trained near Dublin by Jim Dreaper, who was represented by his son, Tom, who said: ldquoKeith was brilliant on her. SP:  ,  ,  .Owner trainer Barry Connell and his retained jockey, Mark Bolger, combined for a smooth success with Enniskerry in the ex racehorses finding their forever home maiden hurdle, second past the post here was Western Cowboy with Danehill Quest back in third.This was a welcome success as the winner was pulled up on its previous outing due to a heart problem.Jockey Jonathan Moore, who missed a notable winner at the Cheltenham Festival due to injury, was back in the winnerrsquos enclosure following the two-mile seven furlong handicap chase, when riding Cloneville Way to victory over Call of the Loon, ridden by Paddy OrsquoHanlon, and Hell on Earth.The winner is trained by the riderrsquos boss, Gavin Cromwell, in Co Meath. SP:  ,  ,   favourite. It was the longest-priced winner of the day.During the final race on the card, the bumper looked sure to go to John Barry and Musta Lovea Lovea as they were well clear with just the climb to the post to go.But right at the post Devils Cut, trained by Denise Sneezy Foster, got up to snatch victory in the process, providing rider Hugh McOwan with his first winning ride in the north. Back in third was The Bandit .Thanks to the efforts of the staff to provide good ground, all races had the maximum runners declared with three reserves also declared.bull Followers of the point-to-points and eventing were shocked to learn of the sudden passing of former point-to-point rider and trainer Philip White, who was a big part of the Route point-to-points over many years.Next Downpatrick meeting is on May .At the first meeting of the year at Ballinrobe last Wednesday, there was a win for Co Down owner Jim Magill when Brooks Falls won the maiden hurdle at   trained by John Ryan. The winner was ridden by Tommy Brett..prettyPhoto

title: Greer raises over £10%2C000 with birthday charity cycle
story: A STRANGFORD man celebrated his th birthday recently by getting on his bike and riding for charity.Greer Lowe was joined by some friends for the -mile ride along the Co Down coast and Ards Peninsula in aid of Mission Aviation Fellowship mdash the worldrsquos largest humanitarian airline. To date, they have raised pound,.Greer, who describes himself as ldquofairly new to cycling, gathered a team of local cyclists to complete a challenging route between Strangford and Dundrum. For some, this was the longest cycle ride they had ever completed.Greer also rallied support from friends and relatives across the globe ndash including his brother in New Zealand and children and grandchildren in Australia and Timor Leste. Greerrsquos international team joined him via WhatsApp for a section of the bike ride.Participating in MAFrsquos  challenge ndash a fundraising campaign to mark the charityrsquos th anniversary ndash Greer decided to mark his special birthday and celebrate MAFrsquos by setting an ambitious pound, fundraising target.The team have been overwhelmed by support from the local community and fundraising has far exceeded what they thought was an impossible target. To date, the team has raised over pound, towards the airlinersquos le-saving work. Greer is particularly grateful to Strangford Fuels, who contributed a generous pound to the cause.Greer has supported MAF for over  years, having developed a keen interest in aviation from a young age.He is particularly fond of the charity because his son, Jonathan, has been a mission pilot with MAF in Timor Leste, and Arnhem Land, Northern Australia, for over a decade. Having visited Jonathan on a number of occasions, Greer describes the unique MAF flying experience as ldquospectacular.With a fleet of  light aircraft, MAF delivers humanitarian personnel, medical cargo and carries out disaster relief operations in remote or inaccessible communities across  developing countries.The charity was founded in the aftermath of WWII by a handful of RAF veterans, and now flies to more remote destinations than any other airline.Departing Strangford at .am in keeping with the  theme, the charity cyclists took the am ferry sailing to Portaferry and completed a -mile route around the southern Ards Peninsula before ing to Strangford and cycling to Dundrum and back, crossing their finish line at pm. During the day, the team cycled over , miles for the cause.From a handful of friends who cycled to keep fit during lockdown, Greer managed to recruit a cohort of enthusiastic cyclists mdash totalling  in dferent parts of the world mdash to join the fundraising marathon to mark his special day. They included his cousin, James Smyth, who also celebrated his th birthday on the same day.One of those who completed their longest ever bike ride as part of the MAF challenge was Leo McGurnaghan, who Greer has got to know through Strangford Costal Rowing Club.Leo said: ldquoI was delighted to be involved in the MAF- mile charity bike ride. Seventy five miles was more than double my previous best. With fellow cyclists and the picturesque Co Down coastline for company, the miles just melted away. With MAF going from strength to strength Irsquom already in training for the centenary celebrations.Greer, who lived and worked in Victoria, Australia, during the s and s, ed to his familyrsquos farm in  and now runs Slievemoyle Cottages with his we, Maureen.With hospitality closed during the pandemic, Greer was able to get out on his bike more often and describes it as a lsquogreat outletrsquo during a dficult season.He said: ldquoCycling has been a way to keep fit with a handful of friends over the past five or six years and our little group from Strangford and Kilclief has grown considerably. As with the rowing club, it has been a wonderful way to make new connections. We are blessed to live in such beautul countryside, and my weekly cycle rides have been a great outlet for me this past year.Despite the impressive distance covered by the team, Greer admits that his ambitious fundraising target has been the most daunting part of the challenge.He said: ldquoI have never set out to raise this much before, and pound, is a very big target. However, MAF is worth it. Their work saves lives in very remote communities across the world ndash some who have no access to any medical or practical help. So, Irsquom overjoyed that we have exceeded our target and Irsquom so grateful for everyone who has supported us so far.ldquoIrsquom also proud of the guys and girls who completed the bike ride with me mdash it was a great day and the conditions were on our side. This will certainly be a birthday to remember.Ruth Whitaker, CEO at MAF-UK said: ldquoGreer and his cycling team have truly gone the extra mile in cycling a very challenging distance and for raising such an impressive amount for MAF.Itrsquos heartening to see people joining from across the world to support MAF and mark Greerrsquos birthday. From everyone at MAF, a very big thank you to everyone who cycled, donated and supported this memorable event.To support Greerrsquos fundraising, visit https:www.justgiving fundraising greer-lowe..prettyPhoto

title: Making a big splash in memory of Ryan
story: THE aunt of a six year-old Downpatrick boy who died  years ago from cancer is to take a bracing dip with  of her closest friends in his memory on Sunday.Lindsey McNabb-Phillips is preparing to brave the cold at Rossglass beach to raise money for CLIC Sargent ndash Young Lives vs Cancer.The charity was a great support to her nephew, six year-old Ryan McNabb, who sadly died two years after being diagnosed with osteosarcoma, a rare bone cancer.Ryan was the son of Marc McNabb and Lynne Berry and attended St Patrickrsquos Primary School, Legamaddy, and St Josephrsquos Primary School, Ballycruttle. He was also survived by an elder sister, Robyn, and a younger sister, Maisie.When news of Ryanrsquos illness became known, his plight touched many hearts and local people got involved in charity initiatives to help him and his family.Lindsey has never tried cold water swimming before but she explained to the Recorder why she decided to try it out for the first time at Rossglass.ldquoThis was Ryanrsquos favourite place. We know he will be looking down on us, laughing his head off at his silly Auntie Lindsey and all her friends, said Lindsey.ldquoThis year would have been Ryanrsquos th birthday. He was such a gorgeous, funny, smart and cheeky boy. Our hearts broke when we got the news he had cancer, and they broke even more when he passed away.ldquoI wanted to mark our th year without him, which also would have been his th birthday, by doing something crazy. We had hoped to do it on his actual birthday but due to Covid- restrictions we had to wait.Lindsey will be joined by her close set of friends she has known for years mdash Amy McPhail, Laura Russell, Leoni Jess, Nicola Spence, Sammie Gawley, Sara Annett, Cara Brown, Grainne Loughran, Karen Mulgrew, Kerrie Macauley, Lynsey Logan, Lisa Noade, Orlagh Webb and Samantha Bogues.ldquoWe will all be meeting up for am and running in together and then probably running out again very quickly, said Lindsey.She said that Ryan loved nothing better than to fish, something he usually did with his dad Marc.ldquoOnce we knew that Ryanrsquos condition was terminal, he loved fishing so much that I contacted the famous angler Matt Hayes and he agreed to spend a day with him fishing. We took him to England and it meant so much to him, recalled Lindsey.ldquoThroughout his treatment and beyond, CLIC Sargent gave him and us so many cherished memories to hold on to ndash we were so very grateful.ldquoThe social care team were amazing and gave us all so much strength to help us through the darkest times. The charity is incredible.Vicki Ewart, fundraising engagement manager for CLIC Sargent Northern Ireland, said: ldquoWe canrsquot thank Lindsey and her friends enough for doing this amazing but baltic challenge and for highlighting the charity, they have raised over pound, already which will help so many families in Northern Ireland.Sadly every week in Northern Ireland another three children and young people aged - are diagnosed with cancer. Normal le stops for them and their families. Treatment is intensive and emotionally gruelling and can last several years.The CLIC Sargent Social Care Team focus on three main areas, financial, emotional and practical support that is tailored to each team.Last year in the Co Down area CLIC Sargent supported  children and young people with a cancer diagnosis.You can make a donation by texting RYAN to  to donate pound,texts cost pound plus one standard rate message, or you can donate on the Just Giving Page at: https:www.justgiving fundraising Lindsey-Mcnabb-Phillips..prettyPhoto

title: New Drumaness riverbank fence
story: PLANS to provide a new palisade fence at the Mill Pond in Drumaness have been welcomed by a local politician.Slieve Croob councillor Cathy Mason said the new fence will be provided between Mill Road and Shanvalley Way in the village.She recently organised a site meeting which was attended by Housing Executive officials and South Down MP Chris Hazzard to discuss the need for a new fence to improve safety.Cllr Mason said the provision of the new fence will come as a ldquogreat relief to many residents who have been increasingly worried as the riverbank had been left dangerously exposed recently as a result of damage to the old wire fencing.She said Sinn Fein is continuing to work with government agencies to identy responsibility for a number of safety issues relating to the Mill Pond area, including an urgent need to maintain the pedestrian footbridge at Shanvalley Way..prettyPhoto

title: Planners give approval for Newcastle FC’s new home
story: FORMAL planning approval has been issued by the Newry, Mourne and Down Council committee for Newcastle Football Clubrsquos ambitious developments for the future.The clubrsquos proposed application for a totally new complex at Church Hill, off the Castlewellan Road, has now been given the green light in what will be a major move for the seaside team.The priority for club officials is the development of three football playing fields, with a focus on a full sized grass pitch which will become the new home to the senior players.An U- grass pitch is also in development, along with an articial G surface also being put forward within the plansClub officials share hopes of a multi-purpose sporting facility to be added in the future, so that the grounds are not restricted solely to soccer.The application for the planning was officially approved last Thursday, with the proposal also entailing surrounding facilities to be added alongside the pitches.Club officials are planning to build a clubhouse, changing facilities, car parking facilities as well as spectator seating, which depending on further easing of restrictions, they will be hoping to make full use of.A new entrance has also been put forward to gain access to the facility, with fencing and gates in the works as well.Despite the planning approval, there is no start date issued as of yet for the beginning of the project..prettyPhoto

title: Residents urged to get Covid jab
story: RESIDENTS across the district who have not yet had their coronavirus jabs are being urged to do so as the unprecedented drive to protect the population continues at pace.The appeal has been issued by Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis and comes after the Department of Health confirmed on Monday evening that there have been no reported Covid cases in Downpatrick and the surrounding areas for the past week.Cllr Lewis mdash who got his jab at the SSE Arena in Belfast last weekend mdash said there are now many dferent opportunities for residents who wish to get the vaccine and understands that there are a number who have not had the jab due to personal circumstances and underlying health issues. However, Cllr Lewis said that for those who are eligible, the options are ied.The politician said local GP surgeries, pharmacies and regional vaccination centres at Belfastrsquos Royal Victoria Hospital and the SSE Arena are offering the jab with people able to book appointments online.He said that to do so, they will need a mobile number or email address along with their health and care number which makes the booking process quicker.Cllr Lewis also praised Stormont health minister Robin Swann his department and the hundreds of staff working at the SSE for the quick and efficient way in which the vaccines are being given. He said there is no delay and no confusion, with people vaccinated, monitored and discharged within  minutes.ldquoTo date, there have been almost .m vaccines given, with almost ten thousand people vaccinated daily and it is worth remembering the progress that our vaccination programme has made in a relatively short period of time, continued Cllr Lewis.ldquoIn less than five months we have vaccinated almost one million people and thousands of our citizens have been able to receive the vaccine well ahead of schedule. I know that we all long for a sustainableto more normal times and vaccination offers the best hope for this.Describing vaccination uptake as ldquovery encouraging, the local councillor said he is pleased that the process is moving so quickly.ldquoIt is my hope that as we move into the summer, we will be able toto some degree of normality, with the increase in the number of people being vaccinated providing the opportunity to increase reopening of businesses, said Cllr Lewis.ldquoNorthern Ireland has suffered and the economy has taken a beating but, together, we will overcome andto a time when we can meet again, dine again and share a laugh with friends while out and about in many cafes, shops, parks and attractions that are ready and waiting to welcome us back.The Department of Health said coronavirus vaccines continued to save lives in Northern Ireland and to protect people from serious illness, with the Astra Zeneca vaccine continuing to be essential in the successful roll-out of the vaccination programme.Following the latest advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation , people aged under  will be offered the Pfizer-BioNTech in Northern Ireland through the regional vaccination centres.Anyone of any age who has had a first dose of Astra Zeneca should proceed with their second dose of this same vaccine, with the JCVI advising that those under  may still make an informed choice to receive the Astra Zeneca vaccine, for instance, where no alternative vaccine is available, or where someone has an appointment booked for vaccination in the coming days and may prefer not to reschedule to receive an alternative vaccine.From the start of this week, people aged  plus can book Astra Zeneca first dose appointments at the SSE Arena vaccination centre and community pharmacies, while people aged - can book their Pfizer first dose appointments at the other regional health trust vaccination centres across the province.The Department of Health says that those aged - can choose to make an informed decision to receive the AstraZeneca vaccine from participating community pharmaciesthat is what they prefer orthey decide they would rather not wait to receive an alternative to the AstraZeneca vaccine.Anyone under  already booked for their first vaccine at one of the health trust centres, including the SSE Arena, will have this appointment honoured with the Pfizer vaccine, while anyone of any age who has received an Astra Zeneca first dose should proceed with their second dose of Astra Zeneca, unless they had an extreme adverse reaction to the first dose.Patricia Donnelly, head of the provincersquos vaccination programme, said protecting the adult population through vaccination was a huge and unprecedented undertaking.She added: ldquoLogistical challenges are inevitable, but the programme has already proved itself to be highly resilient. I would again appeal for patience from the public, as we reset the programme in light of the updated JCVI advice..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield man Denis wins hero accolade
story: A SAINTFIELD man was recently the recipient of a Community Hero award in recognition of the time and effort he selflessly contributed to his area over the years.Denis Conn, who received the award on Community Heroes Day recently, is a long standing and active member of Saintfield Development Association and has played a major role in many of its community events.The nomination for the award, which was submitted to the UK community network, reads: ldquoDenis is an anchorman in the green committee who work relentlessly making Saintfield and the lead roads into it litter-free, colourful and tidy.ldquoHe can be seen in his hi-vis vest and overalls sweeping roads and footpaths, weeding flowerbeds, planting floral displays, watering plants throughout the summer season and strimming grass every week from early spring through to late autumn.The proud community man helps organise regular litter-picks and two cycle runs. In the summer months, Denisrsquos we, Maureen, joins him deadheading the many floral displays every Saturday morning.Denis was also recognised for his winter work within the village when he braves the elements to keep Saintfield clean and tidy.The nomination said: ldquoSaintfield holds a very successful Christmas Fair every year and is always a serious contender in the annual Ulster in Bloom competition.ldquoBoth require funds and Denis excels when bringing voluntary monetary contributions in. This is a reflection on how much Denis is respected in Saintfield by the traders, businesses and residents.Denisrsquos caring for people shows in his actions outside of Saintfield Development Association.He is described as the ldquogo to man and is active within his church and visits the unwell and lonely, running errands and taking them to medical appointments.It was proactive behaviour such as this which led to the nomination to describe Denis proudly as their Community Hero..prettyPhoto

title: School speed limit in Dunsford
story: PLANS for a new mph speed limit outside St Maryrsquos Primary School in Dunsford have been welcomed by two local SDLP politicians.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillor Dermot Curran say the new sign mdash which is being provided as part of a Department for Infrastructure initiative mdash will considerable enhance road safety.Mr McGrath said when Stormont roads minister Nichola Mallon announced plans for a number of new mph zones outside busy primary schools, both he and Cllr Curran knew that the Dunsford school needed to be included.ldquoIt was fantastic to hear that St Maryrsquos had been included and I have no doubt that when the works are complete it will make a real dference to parentsrsquo sense of safety when ping off and picking up their children, he said.ldquoIt will also be a real boost to the school and staff, knowing that drivers are reducing their speed on the approach roads to the school.Mr McGrath said while the new signs will not be in place for another few weeks, he believes it is important that drivers acclimatise themselves and reduce their speed in this area now.He added: ldquoI look forward to seeing how this scheme progresses andthere is scope to extend it to other schools in our local area for the safety and wellbeing of all.Cllr Curran said he and Mr McGrath have asked the government department when the new signs will be provided and were delighted to learn that itrsquos expected to be in the near future.ldquoUnfortunately, there has been a slight delay in their delivery.However, I am confident that as soon as works can begin they will, he added..prettyPhoto

title: Second half sinks Sheehan’s team
story: DOWN senior hurlers had their match winning hopes dashed after a calamitous  minute second-half spell secured the points for a strong Kerry outfit.The final scoreline of - to - does not do full justice to the effort of Ronan Sheehanrsquos men as the DivisIon A opener at Austin Stack Park in Tralee looked very dferent at the half time whistle.The red and black outfit started strongly against an off the pace Kerry side who were battling strong first-half winds, and it wasnrsquot long before the always dangerous Paul Sheehan began chalking up points for Down.Kerry did manage to keep pace with the increasingly confident visitors as Fionan Mackessy, Daniel Collins and Shane Nolan scored points to cover the absence of Shane Conway and Podge Boyle in attack.Down led at the water-break before adding another six points to their total to make the score - to - by the th minute.However, this is when Kerry decided to awaken from their slumber as they added three points to get to within two scores at the halfway mark.The Kingdom commanded the second half right from the start and Down were on the wrong end of two turnovers in as many minutes.This led to two consecutive goals to leave Down in the dust and immediately chasing the game, despite the goalkeeping efforts of Stephen Keith.The Down defence quickly began to crumble and could not weather the storm as Kerry added another goal to make the scoreline - to - by the next water-break.Down regained some composure and managed to steady a sinking ship with Paul Sheehan fought contributing  of Downrsquos points.Tim Prenter was sin-binned after committing a foul on Donal Hunt in what really was the last nail in Downrsquos coffin.Nolan scored the resulting penalty in injury time to widen the margin at the end.The Down manager reflected post-match on that vital second-half display and how it resulted in his team being on the losing side of an entertaining contest.ldquoIt was very disappointing in those  minutes after half-time, Sheehan said. ldquoWe played excellent hurling in the first half, played very well and we seemed to just collapse for some reason.ldquoWe conceded three goals in about five minutes which turned the game on its head. It was a bit inexplicable the way the three goals happened so quickly and two of them came from our own turnovers.This Sunday Down are scheduled to face off against Carlow on home ground with the match set to begin at pm. Carlow will feel confident after defeating Wicklow - to - in their opening match.Down: S Keith M Hughes, C Taggart, J McManus, G Hughes, M Conlon, L Savage , D Hughes , C Egan, P Oacuteg McCrickard, P Sheehan , R Costello , D Sands, E Sands , O McManus.Subs: M Fisher for J McManus , T Prenterfor O McManus , T Murray for G Hughes , J Doran for C Egan , PJ Davidsonfor R Costello , M Patterson for L Savage .Kerry: JB OrsquoHalloran, J Buckley, T OrsquoConnor, E Leen, J Diggins, B OrsquoMahony , F Mackessy , P OrsquoConnor , S Nolan , B Barrett, D Collins , M Leane , M Boyle , F OrsquoSullivan , M OrsquoConnor .Subs: E Murphy for T OrsquoConnor , B Lyons for E Leen , J OrsquoConnor for F Mackessy , D Huntfor M Leane , N OrsquoMahony for B Barrett , D Casey for F OrsquoSullivan , F McCarthy for J Buckley .Kerry -Down -NHL DIVISION A.prettyPhoto

title: Tally set for tough Mayo clash
story: ITrsquoS back to business this Saturday for competitive inter-county football when the Down GAA senior side s to action after a six-month break.Paddy Tallyrsquos men are preparing for a thorough examination upon theirto Division  when they travel to MacHale Park to face Mayo for their first National League game.The Mourne county secured promotion from Division  at the end of last October following an impressive few wins and will be hoping to carry that momentum into the new season.Down are under no illusion about the task that lies ahead after a historically dominant Mayo side was dramatically relegated for the first time in  years from the top flight last October after a pulsating encounter with Tyrone.It is no secret that Down enter this weekendrsquos contest as underdogs considering the recent history of the Yew county.Mayo were once the undisputed kings of the National League, having won six league titles on the spin between  and . They won again in , , , ,  and most recently .Downrsquos opponents have a total of  Allianz league titles with only Kerry and Dublin claiming more.Despite their relegation, Mayo were once again All Ireland finalists, yet failed to break their runners-up curse which has seen them lose their last ten SFC finals, a record no club wish to hold.The last time Down and Mayo went head-to-head was in June , with the Westerners getting the better of Tallyrsquos red and black outfit on that occasion.Ahead of this weekendrsquos clash, Down GAA Supportersrsquo Club members reflected on the previous meetings between the two sides.ldquoThey met in round two of the All-Ireland qualiers in Pairc Esler two years ago and Mayo won by - to -, said a spokesman.ldquoDown had four goal scoring chances but only took one when Gerald Collins gave a fantastic pass to Caolan Mooney who scored a great goal after eight minutes.The Down Supportersrsquo Club hopes that this time around Down can be more clinical between the posts, just like they did nearly a decade ago when they secured a famous away win against Mayo in Castlebar.ldquoThe sides were evenly matched in the second half during their  encounter and Down brought on Benny Coulter who scored two points to make sure of victory as they won by - to -, said the Supportersrsquo Club spokesman.Down manager Tally is also firmly focused on the league after being drawn against Donegal in the preliminary round of the forthcoming Ulster championships.He added: ldquoWe arenrsquot even thinking about that match. The main objective for us is the next game and thatrsquos the start of the league..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. Cows grazed outdoors using a Lely Grazeway This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: superb quality entries at second annual calf fair
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBreed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast.Speaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and ten native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and chairman David Connolly said: Itrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.French judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors.ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.ABERDEEN ANGUSA strong entry of Aberdeen Angus calves were judged by William McLaren from the noted Netherton Herd based at Blackford in Perthshire.Stealing the limelight in the junior section was the -month-old heer, Home Farm Ebony Stunner bred by Fintan Keown, Belleek. She is a daughter of the three-times All Ireland champion Rosemead Karona, and was reserve heer calf champion at the breed clubrsquos calf show a few weeks ago.HEREFORDTaking the reserve junior award was David Wilson, Magheraveely, with the April  heer Lisrace Crystal by Knockmountage Master.Heer born between    and    - , David Wilson, Lisrace Prettymaid th by Ballyaville LelinerBull born after    - , John and William McMordie, Solpoll  National by Solpoll  Dynamite , David Wilson, Lisrace Lumberjack th by Knockmountage Master , Mervyn Richmond, Corraback Kadar by Mara Flook.Heer born after    - , David Wilson, Lisrace Crystal by Knockmountage Master , Mervyn Richmond, Corraback Guenevere th by Mara Flook.IRISH MOILEDThe Irish Moiled classes were judged by Trevor Chadwick from County Offaly. Taking the reserve senior award was the October  Burren Lady, a Knowehead Reuben daughter bred by Nigel Edwards and Michelle McCauley.,The Edwards and McCauley partnership also secured the junior championship at the one-day show with the seven-month-old bull Curraghnakeely Super Duper. CHAROLAISWelshman Arwel Owen placed the strong line-up of Charolais at the Pedigree Calf Fair. Stuart and David Bothwell, Ballinamallard, secured the reserve senior championship with the October  Killadeas Lara, a Goldies Usher daughter out of the home-bred Killadeas Dainty.Heer born between    and    ndash  Gilbert Crawford, Coolnaslee Lucybella by Goldstar Hugo , Stuart and David Bothwell, Killadeas Lara by Goldies Usher.Heer born between    and    ndash , Harold Stubbs and Alan Burleigh, Derryharney Missy by Vexour FreddyBull calf born after    ndash , WD  JA Connolly, Brigadoon Marverick by Goldies Icon , Harold Stubbs and Alan Burleigh, Derryharney Myboy by Hillviewfarm Perfect ,Will Short, Woodpark Marcus by Deeside Gulliver ET.Heer calf born after    ndash , WD and JA Connolly, Brigadoon Milan by Goldies Icon , Harold Stubbs and Alan Burleigh, Derryharney Mygirl by Blelack Blackberet , Jack Smyth, Bessiebell Molly ET by Newhouse Bigal.LIMOUSINBull born between    and    ndash , D and R McFarland, Rayderjem Maverick by Haltclfe DoctorSIMMENTALScottish breeder Iain Green from the noted Corskie Herd in Morayshire praised the quality of Simmentals at the one-day show. Catching his eye to take the senior championship plaudits was the -month-old Scribby Farms George, an Omorga Volvo son, bred by Keith and Andrea Nelson from Rosslea.Pat Kelly, and son Frank, Tempo, secured the junior championship award with the ten-month-old bull Ashland Humdinger. Also by Dermotstown Delboy, he is bred from Ashland Lady Diamond th ndash one of  cows in the herd. title: stormont should today outline a faster exit out of lockdown for northern ireland
story: Roads expert: Delivery of full A upgrade is no longer feasible and by pushing ahead politicians risk ending up with nothing at all   Body found in NI search for missing person after multi-agency search - PSNI say death ‘not being treated as suspicious at this time’NewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsOpinionStormont should today outline a faster exit out of lockdown for Northern IrelandNews Letter editorial on Thursday May  :By EditorialThursday, th May , : am  "       "  ]]News Letter editorialIt is shocking, albeit not surprising, that businesses in Belfast think it will be more than a year before the local economy recovers from the damage of Covid.A Belfast Chamber of Commerce survey of more than  business found that a fth think it will take even longer, more than two years.Lockdown has led to unprecedented barriers to normal trading.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The impact of the restrictions have been utterly unfair, with white collar public sector jobs untouched, able to work from home and given pay rises.Entire industries meanwhile have suffered massive damage, in many cases ruin.Yet the people who issue the orders are untouched: the bureaucrats, the health officials and the politicians.There are still very serious questions that are being asked as to whether such an approach was appropriate for a pandemic that has a very low mortality rate, and which worst affects people who are already near the end of their lives, yet the response impacted severely on non Covid healthcare provision for much younger people.It will be many years before we know the answers to those questions.In the meantime, Northern Ireland must move faster in its exit from lockdown.We cannot be the slowest part of the UK to reopen just because the Republic of Ireland vaccine programme is far behind ours.At the start of lockdown there was no end of complaint about Britain’s approach to the pandemic. Ireland did not hesitate to police the border when it thought it appropriate.Yet Northern Ireland is, in effect, not allowed to police the border in , even when we are far ahead on vaccinations.Stormont should today confirm the May  reopening of outlets such as restaurants, and outline a clear route to changes in mixing of households, travel and tourism, including the essentialof free movement within the Common Travel Area.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make of you.With the coronavirus lockdown having a major impact on many of our advertisers — and consequently the revenue we receive — we are more reliant than ever on you taking out a digital subscription.Subscribe to newsletter and enjoy unlimited access to the best Northern Ireland and UK news and information online and on our app. With a digital subscription, you canthan  articles, see fewer ads, enjoy faster load times, and get access to exclusive newsletters and content. Visit https:www.newsletter subscriptions now to sign up.Our journalism costs money and we rely on advertising, print and digital revenues to help to support them. By supporting us, we are able to support you in providing trusted, fact-checked content for this website.Alistair BusheEditor

title: adventure cinema film food fest  coming bute park
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThey festival has announced its first set of comedy hosts, with the likes of Ivo Graham and Eshaan Akbar set to deliver side-splitting sets.Also confirmed are local street food traders for guests to enjoy from the likes of Bad Boy Burgers and Nomad Waffles, accompanying open-air screenings of family favourites, cult classics and modern blockbusters.Film andFood Fest is also on a mission to find the UKrsquos best short filmmakers to screen their work in a special showcase on the Thursday evening of each event.D images of what the event would look like. Submissions for the showcase can be made through the link below. For more information on tickets for Film andFood Fest, visit filmandfoodfest.Adventure Cinemarsquos inaugural Film andFood Fest will be hosted by some of the UKrsquos most exciting comedians.Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights welcome hilarious comedy names such as Ivo Graham and Eshaan Akbar, who are known for their brilliant appearances on Mock The Week, Live at the Apollo and more and are set to offer a cinema-comedy experience like no other.Ivo Graham was named one of the best young comedians around by Time Out and The Scotsman had to say that Eshaan Akbar is a fine comic entertainer, an intelligent maker of points and a wealth of fascinating facts.Other hosts include Josh Jones who has been named as one of Chortlersquos Ones to Watch in  and has become a regular at some of the biggest comedy clubs in the country.Nomad Waffles - one of the traders that will be at the event. All will be performing stand up sets before the evening movies get under way at Film andFood Fest .The team behind Film andFood Fest have curated a mouth-watering range of street food from local traders to match its blockbuster weekend of movies and comedy.Expect delicious eateries such as The Dog House, who specialise in American cuisine, Battered Shack, where your dreams of eating everything battered can come true and many more.     Think gourmet burgers from Bad Boy Burgers,hand crafted waffles on a stick from Nomad Waffles, to loaded treats from Cheeky Pancake and Asian specials by Desert Island Dumplings.While Friday to Sunday in each city will focus on the big movies such as Dirty Dancing, The Greatest Showman, Joker, Onward and more, Thursday nights are all about short film.Film andFood Fest will feature a special showcase of short movies from some of each regions finest independent filmmakers.Excited to highlight and support the work of local creatives, Film  Food Fest has opened up its submission centre to offer the chance to feature upcoming filmmakers movies on the big screen.For more information on applying, visit https:www.reelsolutions submission-page .Adventure Cinema will also be donating pound from every ticket sold for the short film nights to support local film organisations within each city.To ensure the safety of its events, Film and Food Fest will be taking place exclusively in socially spacious, outdoor venues across the country.There will also be other measures in place, meaning the festival will be -per-cent compliant with government safety guidelines.The ultimate summer stay-cation, adult tickets start at pound. and abooking fee.For afternoon showings, children  years and under go half-price . For more information, visit filmandfoodfest.Ticket holders will be offered a % money-back guarantee should anything mean that the events cannot go ahead.All short film submissions, please visit https:www.reelsolutions submission-page .Full list of destinations:Cardf, Bute Park - th - th JuneNewcastle, Exhibition Park - th - th JuneLeicester, Abbey Park - st - th JulySwansea, Singleton Park - th - th JulyNottingham, Victoria Embankment - th - th JulyLondon , Finsbury Park - nd - th JulyHuddersfield, Greenhead Park - th July - st AugustBristol, The Downs - th - th AugustLiverpool, TBA - th - th August *Venue to be announced soonBournemouth, BH Live Littledown - th - nd AugustLondon , Beckenham Park - th - th AugustLeeds, Roundhay Park - nd - th SeptemberWolverhampton, Bantock Park - th - th SeptemberNorthampton, The Racecourse - th - th SeptemberManchester, Heaton Park - rd - th September article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: four coffee shops penarth meeting friend outdoors
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityTheres nothing quite like enjoying a coffee and tasty treat in the sunshine with your friends.And, of course, that is now all possible once again after April  brought about the reopening of outdoor areas for cafes in Wales.Up to six people or two households can have a catch up while sipping on their favourite caffeinated beverage.With plenty of cafeacutes to choose from in and around the town, it can be hard to pick a place to go for a caffeine fix and a sugar rush.Herersquos our list, and do let us know your favourites too in the comments below.The Crecircpe Escape, Glebe StreetPicture: The Crepe Escape Penarth on FacebookDespite having little outdoor space, they have transformed it into the lsquoSecret Escapersquo and they are hoping to welcome customers on a booking basis in there.They have also teamed up with DoughGo who will be supplying them with their artisan donuts which are all handmade with locally sourced ingredients.The outdoor seating area. Picture: The Crepe Escape on FacebookThe spot is open Monday to Saturday from .am until .pm, and Sunday from am until pm.The Galley, Penarth MarinaBeths Bakes blondies and brownies. Picture: The Galley on FacebookThe Galley, formerly Compass Coffee, is a multi-award winning cafe located in Penarth Marina.Their outdoor seating area is in their car park which overlooks the marina while dining. Bookings are not required for outdoor seating, and all meals and drinks will be served in takeaway contained.They are open Monday to Sunday from am until pm.Willmorersquos , Stanwell RoadPicture: TripAdvisor A Cafe Deli in the heart of Penarth. You order a coffee and cake and sit outside in the sunshine, or alternatively takeaways and collections are available.They open Monday to Thursday from .am until .pm, Friday and Saturday .am until pm and closed on Sunday.Foxys Deli and Cafeacute, Victoria RoadFoxys Deli with the new parklets. Picture: Foxys Deli on FacebookFoxys Deli and cafe in Penarth has been the hub of the community in Penarth for  years and it was recently named one of Britains Best Brunch Venues in The Mail on Sunday.     The cafeacute are even staying open late with a special menu and are teaming up with their neighbours Gin  and serving a menu full of freshly made pizza, lasagne and salads ndash all alongside Gin s delicious gin selection including their own Penarth Gin.They are open Monday to Friday from am until pm, Saturday .am until pm and closed on Sunday. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: oystercatcher penarth undergoes six figure garden makeover
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Oystercatcher, on Terra Nova Way, reopened its garden to happy pub-goers to enjoy their first pulled pint and pub grub since they were closed in December as a result of the coronavirus lockdown.As part of the six-figure garden investment, the Oystercatcher has undergone a complete refurbishment, including a new external bar, five heated huts, external Wi-Fi, new lighting and a newly landscaped garden offering a picturesque view across the bay to enjoy a much needed beer and pub classics.Picture: OystercatcherGeneral manager Andrew Jones said that after such a long period of closure, they are pleased to have their newly renovated garden open for guests to enjoy a ldquowell-deserved pint.MORE NEWS:ldquoThe garden is looking fantastic and it is such an exciting time as we welcome guests, both new and old, he added.Oystercatcher will be offering a full food menu with pub classics including steak and ale pie, fajitas and an extensive range of burgers.Customers will receive table service and will have the option to order via the Greene King order and pay app: www.greeneking-pubs order-and-pay-app . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAhead of the restaurant opening, Burger King UK will be recruiting  restaurant lsquoCrewrsquo members, which span both front of house and kitchen roles at the new Cardf site.Responsibilities include taking customer experience from good, to legendary and ensuring perfect products with exceptional service for every customer. Staff perks include free meals at work plus  per centoff food and drink for friends and family.Five managerial roles will also be created, with Restaurant Sht Manager, Restaurant Assistant Manager, Senior Restaurant Assistant Manager and Restaurant Manager positions currently open for application.Responsibilities include leading and developing teams in a high energy, pacey work environment and providing excellent customer service and quality products, day in, day out.Crew job roles will be released in early May, closer to the opening date of the restaurant, so hopeful candidates should keep checking the website to ensure they donrsquot miss out on these opportunities to join the team in Cardf.MORE NEWS:Amidst the backdrop of a challenging -months for the hospitality industry, the Home of the Whopperis continuing to expand its restaurant portfolio across the UK.JeremyWright, People Director of Burger King UK, said: ldquoDuring what has been a very challenging year for many businesses, we are delighted to be creating new job and career opportunities in the area, and look forward to welcoming  new starters into the Burger King family, at our new Cardf restaurant.ldquoWe continue to be bold and ambitious in our growth plans across both locations and job opportunities.
